india_today.title: Case ordered against BJP Minister over insulting remark on Colonel Sofiya Qureshi
india_today.text: The Madhya Pradesh High Court on Wednesday ordered an FIR against state minister and BJP leader Vijay Shah over his controversial remarks against Colonel Sofiya Qureshi. Meanwhile, the Congress' Madhya Pradesh unit said that they have already filed an FIR today and demanded the minister's dismissal. The development came a day after a viral clip showed Shah making insulting remarks against Qureshi, who was among the officials representing the armed forces during the briefing on Operation Sindoor, causing a huge uproar. A division bench of Justice Atul Shridharan has given strict orders to the Director General of Police to immediately file an FIR against the minister. The court said that the FIR should be filed within four hours under any circumstances. Madhya Pradesh Congress chief Jitu Patwari said that he filed a complaint against Shah over his objectionable remarks. Questioning BJP silence on the issue, he said, "In his address to the nation, PM Modi said that he salutes the valour of the armed forces, and he also said that the whole country stands in support of the armed forces in this difficult time... A minister from Madhya Pradesh insulted the officers of the army and sisters... Why is the BJP silent on this?"

india_today.title: Video: India tests homegrown counter drone system Bhargavastra
india_today.text: Bhargavastra employs unguided micro-rockets as the first layer of defence capable of neutralising swarms of drones with a lethal radius of 20 metres and guided micro-missile as the second layer for pinpoint accuracy. India has successfully test fired a new low-cost counter-drone system called Bhargavastra, marking a significant advancement in tackling the growing threat of drone swarms. The system's micro rockets were successfully tested on Tuesday at the Seaward Firing Range in Odisha's Gopalpur, meeting all specified performance targets. Bhargavastra, designed in hard kill mode, boasts of advanced capabilities for detecting and eliminating small and incoming drones at distances of upto 2.5 km. Two trials were conducted by firing one rocket each. One trial was conducted by firing two rockets in salvo mode within two seconds. All four rockets performed as expected and achieved the required launch parameters, underscoring its pioneering technology in mitigating large-scale drone attacks. Bhargavastra employs unguided micro-rockets as the first layer of defence capable of neutralising swarms of drones with a lethal radius of 20 metres and guided micro-missile (already tested earlier) as the second layer for pinpoint accuracy, ensuring precise and impactful neutralisation. Designed for seamless deployment across diverse terrains, including high-altitude regions (greater than 5,000 m above sea level), the system addresses the unique operational demands of India's armed forces. Highlighting Bhargavastra's adaptability and cost-effectiveness, the SDAL emphasised its indigenous design and the development of dedicated rocket and micro-missile to neutralise hostile UAVs. Furthermore, the system is modular and can have an additional soft-kill layer to include jamming and spoofing to provide an integrated and comprehensive shield for all branches of the armed forces. According to Bhargavastra's developers, the system represents a significant stride in counter-drone technology. Its open-source architecture suggests that while several advanced nations are developing similar micro-missile systems, a domestically conceived multi-layered and cost-effective counter-drone system with swarm neutralisation capabilities like Bhargavastra is yet to be deployed anywhere else globally.

india_today.title: Turkey helped Pak attack India, sent 350+ drones, military operatives
india_today.text: Army releases photos of Pakistani drone debris after neutralizing threat over Amritsar Two Turkish military operatives were killed as part of Operation Sindoor, which reveals that Turkey not only helped Pakistan in its war against India with over 350 drones, but also with operators, sources told India Today TV. According to sources, Turkish advisors helped Pakistani Army officials coordinate drone attacks on India after Operation Sindoor. Pakistan has reportedly used Bayraktar TB2 and YIHA drones against India. The drones are believed to be used for target designation, and potentially kamikaze strikes, especially to threaten forward Indian positions or supply convoys. Turkey's strategic defence ties with Pakistan have grown at an alarming rate in recent years. The Turkish government has not only supplied critical military hardware but has also conducted training for Pakistan's army. In fact, the 'Boycott Turkey' movement gained momentum due to Ankara's growing proximity to Islamabad, which, in turn, harmed Indian interests -- as seen in the recently concluded conflict between South Asian neighbours. Experts believe that the expansion of Indian exports to Turkey following Covid-19 has helped Turkey ramp up its defence production. On the intervening nights of May 7 and 8, the Pakistan Army used around 300–400 drones to target Indian military infrastructure along the northern and western borders. "Forensic investigation of the wreckage of the drones is being done. Initial reports suggest that they are Turkish Asisguard Songar drones," Colonel Sofiya Qureshi said in a press briefing on Operation Sindoor. "The Indian armed forces shot down many of these dones using kinetic and non-kinetic means. The possible purpose of such large-scale aerial intrusions was to test air defence systems and collect intelligence," Colonel Qureshi added. India on Wednesday blocked access to Turkish news outlet TRT on microblogging platform X over Ankara's military support to Islamabad in its recently-concluded four-day conflict with Delhi. In a press briefing on Operation Sindoor, the Army said that Pakistan had used Turkish-made drones to target military infrastructure in 36 locations from Leh to Sir Creek.

india_today.title: Masterstroke or damage-control? BJP's caste census sets ball rolling in Bihar
india_today.text: BJP's move to include caste enumeration in the forthcoming census appeared to be shaped by past electoral setbacks. (File photo) In a politically significant decision ahead of the Bihar Assembly elections, Prime Minister Narendra Modi-led central government has announced that caste enumeration will be conducted alongside the upcoming decennial national census. The move is widely interpreted as a calibrated attempt to counter the opposition INDIA bloc's growing demand for a nationwide caste census — an issue that has gained traction in Bihar's deeply caste-sensitive political landscape. The announcement comes amidst speculation that the BJP is seeking to pre-empt a possible division of Hindu votes along caste lines, which could undermine its electoral prospects in a state where identity politics has historically overshadowed religious consolidation. Bihar had already conducted a state-level caste survey in 2023 under Chief Minister Nitish Kumar-led then Mahagathbandhan government, which included the Janata Dal (United), Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD), and the Congress. The survey’s findings were made public on October 2, 2023. At the time, the decision to undertake the survey had received unanimous support from all parties in the state, including the BJP, which was in the opposition. Yet, demands for a nationwide enumeration persisted, with both Chief Minister Nitish Kumar and his then-deputy Tejashwi Yadav pressing the Centre to take up the issue. Ironically, Congress leader Rahul Gandhi, during recent visits to Bihar, criticised the state-conducted survey and called for a fresh national caste census — despite his party being part of the government that carried out the 2023 exercise. Political analysts view the Centre's decision as both a tactical masterstroke and a damage-control measure. "The BJP has failed to project a strong Hindutva figure like Yogi Adityanath in Bihar and has had to engage with the region’s entrenched caste arithmetic," said Abhay Mohan Jha, a Patna-based political commentator. By embracing caste enumeration, the BJP appeared to be adapting to the ground realities of Bihar's politics, where electoral outcomes have long been shaped more by caste coalitions than communal mobilisation. Analysts suggested that the saffron party is aiming to neutralise one of the Mahagathbandhan's central campaign planks, while simultaneously retaining key allies at the Centre, inlcluding Nitish Kumar and Lok Janshakti Party (Ram Vilas) chief Chirag Paswan. The BJP's move also appeared to be shaped by past electoral setbacks. In the 2015 Bihar elections, Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD) chief Lalu Prasad Yadav had successfully turned the tide in his favour after RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat suggested a review of the reservation policy — fuelling fears among OBCs, SCs, and STs of a rollback in affirmative action. Caste is still the cornerstone of electoral strategy in Bihar, with the RJD banking on its traditional Yadav-Muslim base, and the Janata Dal (United) leaning on support from Kurmis, Koeris, OBCs, and Mahadalits. "Our demand for caste census is longstanding. It will provide accurate data for planning and ensure the development of marginalised communities," Nitish Kumar said in response to the Centre's recent announcement. Deputy Chief Minister Samrat Chaudhary echoed the sentiment from the BJP's side, stating, "The caste census will enable better socio-economic planning for deprived sections of society". RJD supremo Lalu Prasad Yadav hailed the move as a belated acknowledgement of socialist politics. "The first caste survey was done in Bihar under our 17-month Mahagathbandhan government. The issues we raised three decades ago are now setting the national agenda. We'll continue to make these Sanghis dance to our tune," he said. Even Rahul Gandhi welcomed the government's 'sudden' decision to include caste enumeration in the forthcoming census after "11 years of opposing it". He also credited Congress's sustained campaign and said that it was the pressure put by the grand old party on the government for the caste census has worked. "It doesn't matter what the BJP thinks. We have shown that we can pressure the BJP into doing the caste census," Gandhi said at a press conference. "We wholeheartedly welcome this decision but demand a clear implementation timeline," the Gandhi scion said.

india_today.title: India test fires Bhargavastra: How it goes into hard kill mode
india_today.text: Bhargavastra employs a multi-layered defence mechanism. Days after India thwarted Pakistani drone swarm attacks following Operation Sindoor, India has successfully test-fired its indigenous Bhargavastra counter-swarm drone system. The test, conducted at the Seaward Firing Range in Gopalpur, Odisha, showcased Bhargavastra’s ability to detect, lock onto, and neutralise multiple drones simultaneously-a critical need amid rising drone threats. Developed by Solar Defence and Aerospace Limited (SDAL), Bhargavastra is a low-cost, modular system designed for rapid deployment across diverse terrains, including high-altitude regions above 5,000 metres. #WATCH | A new low-cost Counter Drone System in Hard Kill mode 'Bhargavastra', has been designed and developed by Solar Defence and Aerospace Limited (SDAL), signifying a substantial leap in countering the escalating threat of drone swarms. The micro rockets used in this pic.twitter.com/qM4FWtEF43— ANI (@ANI) May 14, 2025 Bhargavastra employs a multi-layered defence mechanism: Neutralisation (Hit): Bhargavastra’s first layer launches unguided micro rockets, creating a lethal radius of 20 metres and neutralising drone swarms at distances up to 2.5 km. Bhargavastra’s modular design allows for the integration of additional “soft kill” options, such as jamming and spoofing, providing a comprehensive shield against a wide range of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) threats. The successful test shows India’s growing capability to counter sophisticated aerial threats, offering the armed forces a robust tool to safeguard sensitive zones and critical infrastructure.

india_today.title: Turkey aided Pak, but its Celebi handles high-security tasks at Indian airports
india_today.text: Turkish aviation company, Celebi, handles operations across major airports in India, managing over 5,40,000 tonnes of cargo annually. (Image for representation/Unsplash) Turkey has supplied armed drones and operators to Pakistan during the latest military confrontation and what should be of concern is that a Turkish joint-venture company, Celibi Aviation, handles high-security tasks at eight Indian airports, including in Delhi, Mumbai and Chennai. It manages 58,000 flights in India annually. Many of the tasks that Celebi Aviation performs in India -- especially those related to ground handling, cargo management, and airside operations -- are considered high-security jobs due to the sensitive and regulated nature of the airport environment. Its staff operate in airside zones, which are high-security areas of airports, and come in direct contact with aircraft. Celebi staff also handle cargo logistics and passenger baggage, including items destined for international flights. Turkey provided military assistance to Pakistan as it tried to swarm the Indian air defence system after India struck terror camps in Pakistan and Pakistan-occupied Kashmir (POK) on May 7 as part of Operation Sindoor. Not just military drones, Turkey provided Pakistan with operatives to handle those drones, showing that it joined in with Pakistan to attack India, sources told India Today TV. Turkey has taken an Islamic turn under President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and taken Pakistan's side on the Kashmir issue. India assisted Turkey with relief material after the massive 2023 earthquake, launching Operation Dost. However, it would likely be considering the status after it came to light that Istanbul provided personnel to operate the drones and assisted in the attack on India. Celebi, performing high-security tasks at several key airports in India, might also be seen as a red flag. The airlines serviced by Celebi Aviation in India include IndiGo and Air India among others. Since its entry in 2008, Celebi has expanded its presence in India's aviation sector. It handles over 58,000 flights and 5,40,000 tons of cargo annually, with a workforce of 7,800 employees, according to its official website. Celebi entered India with a joint venture at Mumbai International Airport, where it was mandated to provide ground handling services. Within a year, Celebi officially registered its operations in India under two entities: Celebi Airport Services India for ground handling and Celebi Delhi Cargo Terminal Management India for cargo services at New Delhi International Airport. Celebi's services in India include passenger services, load control and flight operations, ramp services, general aviation services, cargo and postal services, warehouse services, and bridge operations. Celebi Aviation Holdings conducts nearly 75 percent of its business with foreign carriers, while the remaining 25 percent is with Indian airlines, according to a Moneycontrol report. Celebi Aviation has been looking to expand its footprint in the Indian aviation market for years. During the Air India privatisation process, the company in 2016 expressed interest in acquiring Air India’s ground handling unit, the Air India Airport Services Limited (AIASL). Celebi stepped into the aviation industry with Celebi Ground Handling in 1958. It was Turkey's first privately owned ground-handling services company, according to the company website. It operates in 70 airports in six countries across three continents, according to the Celebi website. The high-security jobs that some Celebi staff perform need background checks and Airport Entry Passes (AEPs) issued by aviation security authorities like BCAS (Bureau of Civil Aviation Security). While Celebi is registered in India and its staff are background-checked, it being of Turkish origin might cause some discomfort because of the sensitive and high-security tasks its staff are engaged in at airports.

india_today.title: Pak returns BSF jawan to India 20 days after he accidentally crossed border
india_today.text: BSF constable Purnam Kumar Shaw had accidentally crossed the border. (Image: India Today) BSF constable Purnam Kumar Shaw, who had been in the custody of Pakistan Rangers since April 23, was handed back to Indian authorities on Wednesday morning. In an official statement, the BSF said, "Today at 1030 hrs, Constable Purnam Kumar Shaw has been taken back from Pakistan by the BSF at the Attari - Wagha border. Constable Purnam Kumar Shaw had inadvertently crossed over to Pakistani territory while on operational duty in the area of Ferozepur sector on 23rd April 2025 around 1150 hrs and was detained by Pak Rangers." BSF jawan's family said that it was a "great relief" and thanked the government for securing his return. "We are very happy today. We thank the central government and the BSF authorities for their efforts in safely bringing him back. The past two weeks have been filled with sleepless nights and uncertainty for us. We were constantly worried about his well-being," a family member of Shaw told reporters. Following BSF jawan's return to India, the Trinamool Congress wrote on X, "Home at last. After days of anxiety and uncertainty, BSF Jawan Purnam Kumar Shaw has finally been repatriated. Mamata Banerjee personally reached out to his wife multiple times, offering reassurance and support during the ordeal. We wish Purnam a full recovery from the trauma he endured and hope he finds peace in the embrace of his loved ones." West Bengal BJP president Sukanta Majumdar thanked PM Narendra Modi on X. He wrote, "A heartfelt thank you to Hon’ble Prime Minister Shri @narendramodi Ji for once again proving that under your strong and decisive leadership, no Indian is ever left behind. Today, the safe return of @BSF_India jawan Shri Purnam Kumar Shaw, who was in Pakistan's custody since April 23, is not just a moment of relief—it's a victory of India's resolve, diplomacy, and national pride. Your relentless commitment to the nation's security and dignity has ensured justice and honor for our brave soldiers." BSF jawan Shaw of the 182nd Battalion was detained by Pakistan Rangers on April 23 after he inadvertently crossed the International Border near Ferozepur, Punjab. Shaw was on duty near the border fence and in uniform, carrying his service rifle, when he reportedly moved towards a shaded area to rest. In the process, he unknowingly crossed into Pakistani territory, where he was apprehended by the Pakistan Rangers. Following his detention, officials from both the Indian Army and Pakistan Rangers had initiated a flag meeting to resolve the matter and secure the jawan's release. Notably, the jawan accidentally crossed the border a day after the dastardly April 22 Pahalgam terror attack in which terrorists opened fire in the Baisaran valley, killing 26 people.

india_today.title: Creative naming can't alter reality: India rejects China's Arunachal renaming
india_today.text: India firmly rejected China’s latest attempt to rename several locations in Arunachal Pradesh, reiterating that the state remains an integral part of the country. This comes two days after China’s Civil Aviation Ministry on May 11-12 released new names for 27 locations in Arunachal Pradesh in another attempt to assert claims over Indian territory. In a strongly worded statement, the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) said on Tuesday, “We have noticed that China has persisted with its vain and preposterous attempts to name places in the Indian state of Arunachal Pradesh.” The MEA added, “Consistent with our principled position, we reject such attempts categorically. Creative naming will not alter the undeniable reality that Arunachal Pradesh was, is, and will always remain an integral and inalienable part of India.” The MEA’s reaction comes after China’s repetitive attempt to assert its claim on Arunachal Pradesh. Earlier in April 2024, China had released a fourth list of 30 new names of various places along the line of actual control (LAC) in India's northeastern state of Arunachal Pradesh last year in 2024. This was not the first time China tried to rename places inside Indian territory. China released a list of so-called 'standardised' geographical names in Arunachal Pradesh, which Beijing recognises as Zangnan, state-run Global Times reported. The 30 places renamed by Bejing include 12 mountains, four rivers, one lake, one mountain pass, 11 residential areas and a piece of land. Apart from the list of names, the Chinese ministry also shared detailed latitude and longitude and a high-resolution map of the areas. In 2017, Beijing had released the initial list of 'standardised' names for six locations in Arunachal Pradesh. This was succeeded by a second list comprising 15 places in 2021, with another list featuring names for 11 additional places released in 2023. Meanwhile, India has stayed firm in its rejection of China's attempt to claim territories in Arunachal Pradesh, asserting that the state is an integral part of the country and assigning 'invented' names does not alter this reality.

india_today.title: Lashkar, terror allies glorify Pak military op, threaten India at Karachi rally
india_today.text: Analysts warn that by allowing religious extremists to serve as mouthpieces for military operations, Pakistan risks further damaging its international image, alienating moderate voices, and entrenching violent ideologies within its borders. In a concerning development that underscores the deepening nexus between Pakistan’s military and radical Islamist elements, a series of orchestrated gatherings across Pakistan have been held to glorify the Pakistan Army’s so-called "Operation Bunyan Marsoos" with extremist rhetoric flowing freely from the stage. Radical clerics and leaders from banned and controversial groups assembled under the umbrella of the Difa-e-Watan Council (DWC) -- an alliance known for hosting extremist ideologues -- to heap praise on the military’s role in the aftermath of Operation Sindoor in Karachi on Tuesday evening. Among the groups actively participating were Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT) and Ahl-e-Sunnat Wal Jamaat, both designated terror organisations. These events, carefully choreographed to appear as spontaneous outpourings of national pride, were instead marked by incendiary speeches, veiled threats to India, and glorification of religious warfare. Praising the Pakistan Army’s actions, Masood declared: "Our enemy calls our army a religious army and those who are traitors to the country call this army a secular army After winning this war, we came to know and became convinced that our army is not a secular army. It is an army that has the passion for martyrdom and sacrifices its life in the name of religion and Islam, in the name of Allah." Adding to the provocative narrative, Allama Rashid Mahmood Soomro, General Secretary of Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam (Sindh), openly threatened India while reinforcing the clerical establishment’s allegiance to the military: "My leader Maulana Fazlur Rehman challenged Modi from Minar-e-Pakistan Lahore... We told Modi that we like to have breakfast in India... we also like to hoist the flag of Pakistan over Delhi." "By shooting down Rafale, we destroyed the blood of Europe by destroying S-400, it has also told Russia...you should think a hundred times before messing with Pakistan," he added. Analysts warn that by allowing religious extremists to serve as mouthpieces for military operations, Pakistan risks further damaging its international image, alienating moderate voices, and entrenching violent ideologies within its borders.

india_today.title: Pakistan receives 2nd IMF payout as India raises concerns
india_today.text: India has raised serious concerns about Pakistan getting more financial help. (Photo: GettyImages) Pakistan has received another round of financial support from the International Monetary Fund (IMF). This time, the country got around $1.02 billion under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF), which is a long-term loan programme. It wrote on X, “SBP has received the second tranche of SDR 760 million (US$ 1,023 million) from the IMF under the EFF program. The amount will be reflected in SBP’s foreign exchange reserves for the week ending on 16th May 2025.” This payment is part of the second instalment of a $7 billion IMF loan deal that began in September 2024 and will run for 37 months. With this latest inflow, the total funds given to Pakistan so far under the EFF have reached $2.1 billion. The funds were cleared after a review meeting held by the IMF’s Executive Board on 9 May. In the same meeting, Pakistan was also granted an extra $1.4 billion under the Resilience and Sustainability Facility (RSF). This special funding aims to help countries tackle climate change challenges and improve disaster preparedness. However, not everyone is pleased with this support. India chose not to vote at the IMF meeting and raised serious concerns about Pakistan getting more financial help. In its official remarks, India said that Pakistan has a poor track record of using IMF loans properly and has been relying on bailouts for far too long. While Pakistan has welcomed the financial lifeline, India’s objections highlight the growing international debate on how such funds are used and whether they actually lead to real change on the ground.

india_today.title: BCCI changes replacement rules for remainder of IPL 2025 season: Report
india_today.text: The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) has reportedly changed its player replacement policy for the remainder of the IPL 2025 season. All 10 franchises have now been allowed to sign temporary replacements for the rest of the tournament. Earlier, the replacement player rules for IPL 2025 permitted such changes only in cases of injury or illness before a team's 12th league match. The replacement rules have been revised as the IPL 2025 is set to resume on May 17 after a one-week suspension caused by military tensions between India and Pakistan. The BCCI has reportedly made the decision to address player availability issues, particularly among overseas cricketers who are unable to return due to national duties, personal reasons, or injuries. However, players signed as temporary replacements under the new rule will not be eligible for retention ahead of the IPL 2026 auction. These players must re-enter the pool through the next auction if they are to return to the league. According to ESPNcricinfo, in a memo sent to franchises, the IPL stated: "Given the non-availability of certain foreign players due to national commitments or personal reasons or any injury or illness, Temporary Replacement Players will be allowed until the conclusion of this tournament. This decision is subject to the condition that the Temporary Replacement players taken from this point forward will not be eligible for retention in the following year." The league also clarified that replacements approved before the suspension remain unaffected by the rule change and will still be eligible for retention. These include Sediqullah Atal (Delhi Capitals), Mayank Agarwal (Royal Challengers Bengaluru), and Nandre Burger and Lhuan-dre Pretorius (both Rajasthan Royals), all signed shortly before the tournament was paused. Australian batter Jake Fraser-McGurk, who was bought by Delhi Capitals for Rs 9 crore at the mega auction, has informed the franchise that he will not return for the remainder of the season. The DC management has signed Mustafizur Rahman as Fraser-McGurk's replacement for Rs 6 crore. The Bangladesh pacer, who previously represented DC in the 2022 and 2023 seasons, returns for a third stint but will not be eligible for retention under the updated guidelines. The rule change is intended to give teams greater flexibility during the final stretch of the season while ensuring clarity around long-term squad planning. With the league entering its closing stages, franchises now have the opportunity to reinforce their squads, even if only temporarily, despite the limited availability of several key players.

india_today.title: Op Sindoor: India clear winner in air battle against Pak, says aviation expert
india_today.text: Military historian Tom Cooper said that India was a clear winner in the air battle against Pakistan. Military historian and aviation analyst Tom Cooper, while talking to India Today, said that India was a clear winner in the air battle against Pakistan. This comes after India launched Operation Sindoor in retaliation to the April 22 Pahalgam terror attack, and Pakistan responded with aerial attacks across border towns using missiles and drones last week. "And when you see that Pakistani ground-based air defence system has been hit, then the Pakistani air force has been pushed away from the border to India," he added. INDIA TODAY EXCLUSIVE | Military historian hails #OperationSindoor : He also explains why #Pakistan was not being able to deploy its air defence systems. pic.twitter.com/fOt4Pimhkz— IndiaToday (@IndiaToday) May 13, 2025 "This also meant that the Indian air force was able to go closer to the Pakistani airspace and launch its missiles deep inside Pakistan," he added. "And the final nail in the coffin was when India not only hit Pakistani airbases but, and I know this is contrary to the official statements, when it started hitting nuclear weapons storage facilities," Cooper said. On being asked about why Pakistan was not able to employ its air defence system effectively, the military historian added that there was a fundamental switch in India's strategy, and in this case, "all of a sudden, the politics changed its opinion". "What's interesting is your armed forces' ability to adapt and act accordingly," he further said. Tom Cooper also said that the world knew about India's capability, but it was never demonstrated before. "And all of a sudden, within 24 hours, India showed that it can hit Pakistan this hard," he added. In a pre-dawn operation on May 10, the Indian Air Force (IAF) carried out precision strikes on 11 military sites deep inside Pakistan using air-launched weapons. The targeted locations included key airbases in Rafiqui, Murid, Nur Khan, Rahim Yar Khan, Sukkur, Chunian, Pasrur, and Sialkot, according to the Ministry of Defence.

india_today.title: Tesla Optimus robot shows impressive dance moves in new video
india_today.text: Tesla’s humanoid robot Optimus is back in the limelight, and this time, it’s not for factory tasks or tech upgrades — it’s for dancing. A short video shared by Elon Musk on the social media platform X shows the robot performing fluid and expressive dance moves, prompting many viewers to wonder if what they saw was even real. The video quickly gained traction, with millions of views and widespread engagement. While some social media users questioned whether the clip was generated using artificial intelligence, Musk clarified that the footage was genuine and happening in real time. X’s own chatbot, Grok, also responded to one user’s query, stating the clip likely showed the actual Optimus robot. The AI cited previous demonstrations, including Tesla’s ‘We, Robot’ event in October 2024 and updates from April 2025, as proof that the robot had already shown off basic tasks like walking and coordination. Social media users were both amused and amazed. One user joked about turning Optimus into a wall painter, saying Tesla would sell millions if that were the case. Another praised the robot’s capabilities, suggesting that such innovations could reduce work-related physical injuries once deployed at scale. Tesla originally revealed its plans for a humanoid robot during its AI Day in 2021, though at that time it was more of a concept — quite literally, with a person dressed in a robot costume dancing on stage. In 2022, Tesla brought early prototypes to life, showcasing limited but functioning mobility. Since then, the robot has gradually developed into a more advanced machine capable of carrying out simple real-world tasks. The new video suggests that Tesla is not only making technical progress but also building public interest in Optimus through relatable moments. Whether the robot will be painting walls, working in warehouses or helping at home, the latest glimpse adds to the growing curiosity about its future role in society.

india_today.title: Toyota unveils Corolla Cross GR Sport facelift
india_today.text: Toyota has revealed the 2026 Corolla Cross, introducing a refreshed design and a new GR Sport variant that adds a bold, performance-inspired edge to the compact SUV. Unveiled for global markets, the updated Corolla Cross combines hybrid efficiency with sportier styling and handling enhancements. The 2026 Corolla Cross GR Sport features a distinctive front bumper and grille. The honeycomb grille, paired with larger corner air intakes and a deeper apron, gives the car a more aggressive stance. Glossy black Toyota logos and fully machined 19-inch black alloy wheels further enhance its sporty aesthetic. An exclusive Storm Grey bi-tone paint option with a black roof adds a unique flair to the GR Sport. The rear design includes updated C-shaped LED taillights with integrated aero fins for improved stability and an embossed Corolla Cross logo. The Corolla Cross GR Sport is powered by Toyota’s fifth-generation hybrid system, available in two configurations: Inside, the GR Sport variant elevates the cabin with all-black upholstery, red contrast stitching, GR-embroidered headrests and aluminium pedals. The entire Corolla Cross range benefits from a redesigned centre console with increased storage, a smartphone storage area, sliding storage box, and updated cupholders. The car offers a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster and a 10.5-inch infotainment touchscreen. Other features include like a panoramic sunroof, ambient lighting, Level 2 ADAS, seat heating and a heated steering wheel.

india_today.title: Words of war: What are AWACS?
india_today.text: The image of a large aircraft with a distinctive dome-shaped radar atop its fuselage can be striking. Known as AWACS, this aircraft plays a pivotal role in modern aerial warfare. But what exactly is this formidable-looking plane? AWACS stands for Airborne Warning and Control System. The term gained public attention during moments of heightened aerial activity, such as the 2019 air skirmish between Indian and Pakistani forces following the Balakot airstrike. However, AWACS is actually a more commonly used term for a broader category of airborne combat systems technically called AEW&CS—Airborne Early Warning and Control System. Much like “Xerox” became synonymous with photocopying, AWACS is often used interchangeably with AEW&CS.

india_today.title: 'Couldn't recognise him': Wife of BSF soldier freed after 20 days in Pak custody
india_today.text: Following BSF constable Purnam Kumar Shaw's release, Mamata Banerjee called Rajani on the phone and extended her best wishes to the couple. The wife of BSF constable Purnam Kumar Shaw -- who was released from the custody of Pakistan Rangers earlier in the day -- expressed joy and disbelief, saying she could hardly recognise him on video call. "We are happy. I saw my husband on a video call. I saw him after 22 days. I couldn’t even recognise him because his beard had grown so much. He said he is safe and sound. We are thankful to the BSF and the central government. The country stood with us," she told India Today TV. Trinamool Congress celebrated Purnam's release, tweeting, "Home at last. After days of anxiety and uncertainty, BSF Jawan Purnam Kumar Shaw has finally been repatriated. Mamata Banerjee personally reached out to his wife multiple times, offering reassurance and support during the ordeal. We wish Purnam a full recovery from the trauma he endured and hope he finds peace in the embrace of his loved ones." Fourty-year-old Purnam, who was posted in Punjab's Ferozepur sector, accidentally crossed over to Pakistan on April 23. He has been kept in the custody of Pakistani Rangers since then. Following his capture, officials from India and Pakistan initiated a flag meeting to secure his release.

india_today.title: Realme GT 7 and GT 7T India launch set for May 27: What to expect
india_today.text: Realme is all set to expand its Realme GT 7 series in India, with two new phones expected to join the GT 7 Pro — the Realme GT 7 and GT 7T. For those who don’t know, Realme has already released the GT 7 duo in China, but until the Indian versions are officially unveiled, we can’t be certain how similar they’ll be to their Chinese counterparts. Interestingly, the Chinese variant of the GT 7 closely resembles what is being referred to as the GT 7T in India. In fact, there isn’t a GT 7T model in China at all. On top of that, the Indian version of the GT 7 isn’t getting the Dimensity 9400+ chip found in the Chinese variant. It’s a bit of a confusing situation, which is why we’re focusing solely on the Indian versions of the upcoming Realme GT 7 phones. Here’s everything we know so far. Realme has officially confirmed that both the GT 7 and GT 7T will launch globally — including in India — on May 27. The launch event is set to take place in Paris, France, with the start time scheduled for 1:30 PM IST. Both phones are expected to go on sale via Realme’s official website, Amazon India, and across other online and offline retail channels. While Realme hasn’t revealed any pricing just yet, we can take some clues from last year’s GT 6 series. The Realme GT 6 and GT 6T launched in India at starting prices of Rs 40,999 and Rs 30,999, respectively. So, it’s fair to expect the GT 7 and GT 7T to be priced similarly. Realme GT 7 series: Specs and expected features Unlike its Chinese counterpart, which runs on the Dimensity 9400+ chip, the Indian version of the Realme GT 7 is confirmed to be powered by the MediaTek Dimensity 9400e processor. It’s also expected to pack a massive 7,000mAh battery with support for 120W fast charging. The Chinese version features a slightly larger 7,200mAh battery, but what’s coming to India still looks very promising. Another highlight is that the Realme GT 7 is being marketed as the world’s first smartphone to feature a graphene cooling layer beneath both the rear panel and the display. This should, at least in theory, deliver improved thermal management and help the phone stay cool even under intense use. The phone is also confirmed to be available in two colour options: IceSense Blue and IceSense Black. Other key features expected on the Realme GT 7 include a 6.78-inch full-HD+ OLED display with a 144Hz refresh rate, a dual rear camera setup with a 50-megapixel primary sensor, and a 16-megapixel front-facing camera for selfies and video calls. As for the Realme GT 7T, there’s still limited information available about the device. So far, it’s said to launch with 8GB RAM. The device carries the model number RMX5085 and has reportedly been spotted on the TKDN certification site in Indonesia. Realme has also confirmed that the GT 7T will come with NFC support. Additionally, it will feature something called INT, which is believed to function similarly to Apple’s Intercom feature — allowing users to send and receive short voice messages between devices, such as from one GT 7T to another, or across compatible Realme devices. According to the phone’s official landing page, the Realme GT 7T will come in three colours: blue, black and a signature yellow with a black strip design.

india_today.title: IIM Ahmedabad graduate quits 6-figure salary job at Amazon to pursue career in music
india_today.text: The IIM Ahmedabad alumnus who left his high-paying job at Amazon to chase his dream. (Photos: Shravan Tickoo/LinkedIn) An Indian Institute of Management (IIM) Ahmedabad alumnus who once worked as a product manager at Amazon gave up his corporate career to follow his passion for music. A post about his journey has now gone viral. Anil Jangid, a former product manager at Amazon and an IIM Ahmedabad graduate, chose to step away from a stable career to become a singer. His friend Shravan Tickoo shared his story in a heartfelt LinkedIn post that has drawn admiration from users online.

india_today.title: All overseas players barring Jamie Overton, Sam Curran available for CSK: CEO
india_today.text: Sam Curran will not return to play for CSK in the remainder of IPL 2025 (PTI Photo) Chennai Super Kings will be without England all-rounders Jamie Overton and Sam Curran for the remainder of the IPL 2025 season, which resumes on May 17. The five-time champions will have all their remaining overseas players for their last two fixtures in the group stages, CEO Kasi Viswanathan told IndiaToday.in on Wednesday, May 14. "Jamie Overton and Sam Curran are not available. Others are coming," Kasi Viswanathan said. The availability of overseas players has become a cause for concern in the lead-up to the resumption of the IPL. Several overseas players returned home after the BCCI announced a week-long suspension of the IPL due to cross-border tensions between India and Pakistan in the aftermath of the April 22 terrorist attack in Pahalgam, Jammu and Kashmir.

india_today.title: Akashteer explained: India's iron dome-style shield that foiled Pakistani drone threats
india_today.text: Akashteer explained: India’s iron dome-style shield that foiled Pakistani drone threats (File photo: PTI) In the recent military engagement, India's defence forces demonstrated remarkable efficiency and technological superiority. Central to this success was the deployment of the Akashteer system, an advanced air defence command and control mechanism that played a pivotal role in neutralising aerial threats and safeguarding the nation's mainland. Akashteer's performance in Operation Sindoor exemplifies the critical role of advanced technology in modern warfare. As India continues to develop and deploy indigenous defence technologies, systems like Akashteer will be central to maintaining national security and strategic superiority. Developed by Bharat Electronics Limited (BEL) under the 'Atmanirbhar Bharat' initiative, Akashteer is a fully automated and integrated air defence system designed to enhance the speed, coordination, and effectiveness of India's air defence operations. During Operation Sindoor, the Akashteer system was instrumental in countering Pakistan's offensive maneuvers. Its interoperability with India's Akash surface-to-air missile batteries, Spyder systems, and indigenous radar networks like Rohini and Arudhra allowed for seamless coordination and precision engagement of intrusions from Pakistan’s airspace. The successful deployment of Akashteer during Operation Sindoor not only neutralised immediate threats but also sent a strong message regarding India's defence capabilities.

india_today.title: Are Indian exports to Turkey powering its drones?
india_today.text: India has always considered Turkey a close friend, and Operation Dost is evidence of that. Following the massive earthquake that hit Turkey in 2023, India sent more than 250 personnel, specialised equipment, and relief material. But now, it seems things have changed. Pakistan attacked India with around 400 Turkish drones in four days. And, it’s not that Turkey did not know what Pakistan would do with those drones. Turkey’s strong alignment with Pakistan appears to be a new development. Reports also suggest that since 2024, Turkey has put a blanket ban on defence-related exports to India. However, in 2021, an Indian firm, with an investment of USD 1 million, bought a 30 per cent share in the Turkish unmanned aerial vehicle producer Zyrone Dynamics. The two companies signed a partnership agreement at the International Defence Industries Fair in Istanbul, Turkey. The government of India called it a new beginning and a welcome Indian investment in the defence sector. A new beginning - welcome Indian investment in the defence sector.. Partnership agreement between @DCMShriramLtd of India and @zyronedynamics of Turkey signed at #IDEF2021 in Istanbul in the presence of @AmbSanjayPanda @SSB_Eng @anadoluagency @ANI @airnewsalerts pic.twitter.com/DkSBW0q9k2— IndiaInTrkiye (@IndiaInTurkiye) August 18, 2021 It was only during the recent tensions with Pakistan that Turkey’s stance was revealed. Not only did Turkey call India’s retaliatory actions after the Pahalgam attack provocative, but it also condemned them. In contrast, it said, “We support Pakistan’s call for an investigation into the April 22 terrorist attack.” The answer is yes. While Turkey has banned the sale of drones and other arms to India, a large portion of India’s exports to Turkey can be used in making drones. India’s exports to Turkey have increased post-COVID-19, and engineering goods account for the largest chunk. Aluminium and aluminium products, auto components, aircraft and parts, telecom instruments, electric machinery and equipment, are among India’s major exports to Turkey.

india_today.title: Bangladesh calls for regional economic plan with India's Northeast, Nepal, Bhutan
india_today.text: Bangladesh’s Chief Adviser Muhammad Yunus has called for a joint economic strategy involving India’s northeastern states, Nepal, Bhutan, and Bangladesh, underlining the need for regional cooperation in hydropower, healthcare, and road connectivity. “There should be an integrated economic plan for Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan and the Seven Sisters,” Yunus said, referring to India’s northeastern states. “We have more to gain together than apart.” One of the key focus areas was regional energy cooperation, especially hydropower. Yunus and Rana discussed the Bangladesh-Nepal-India tripartite agreement signed in October last year, under which Bangladesh is importing 40 MW of power from Nepal using Indian transmission lines. Both sides agreed there was room for larger-scale hydropower projects. Yunus also said that Bangladesh is committed to expanding access to healthcare for neighbouring countries. “Our upcoming 1,000-bed hospital in Rangpur will be open to patients from Nepal and Bhutan as well. We believe in regional health security and shared prosperity,” he added. Rana expressed Nepal’s interest in stronger bilateral ties and said, “All our parliamentarians want to work closely with Bangladesh. We’re serious about strengthening our economic partnership and boosting people-to-people connections.” Muhammad Yunus has referred to India's Northeast on more than one occasion in the past couple of months. During his China visit in March, Yunus had made a pitch to Beijing that included India's seven northeastern states. While urging Beijing to establish an economic foothold in Bangladesh by leveraging its strategic position as the "only guardian of the ocean" in the region, Yunus said, "The seven states of India, the eastern part of India, are called the Seven Sisters. They are a landlocked region of India. They have no way to reach out to the ocean." The remark had drawn a sharp reaction from Indian leaders. Experts had also flagged that China's growing influence in its immediate neighbourhood would be of concern to India. Bangladesh is of strategic importance to India, and several places in the country are close to the Siliguri Corridor, also referred to as the Chicken's Neck, a tiny strip of land that connects the northeast states to the rest of India.

india_today.title: Woman leaving job for children not voluntary desertion, entitled to alimony: Court
india_today.text: The Delhi High Court has held a woman leaving her job to take care of her child as a single parent wasn't voluntary desertion of work and she was entitled to alimony. "It is well settled that the responsibility of caregiving to a minor child falls disproportionately upon the parent with custody, often limiting their ability to pursue full-time employment, especially in cases where there is no family support to take care of the child while the mother is at work," the court said. The verdict, therefore, noted the cessation of employment by the woman cannot be viewed as "voluntary abandonment of work, but as a consequence necessitated by the paramount duty of child care". The man argued that the family court erred in not considering the fact that the woman left her matrimonial home on her own volition and did not resume her ties with the husband despite a court order. The woman, on the other hand, submitted she was unable to work owing to her responsibilities towards the child. She said her past employment wasn't a valid ground to deny her rightful maintenance and argued since it took long hours to commute and she couldn't find work near home, she gave up her teaching career.

india_today.title: INS Vikrant-led 36-ship armada was in position to hit Karachi: Sources
india_today.text: INS Vikrant was among the warships that blockaded Karachi port during Operation Sindoor, according to sources. In a significant escalation of maritime readiness, the Indian Navy deployed 36 frontline naval assets, including INS Vikrant and several submarines, near Karachi during Operation Sindoor, according to sources. This marked a sharp contrast to the six warships mobilised during the 1971 operations targeting the city. Following the recent terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pahalgam in which 26 people were killed, India launched a tri-pronged pressure strategy on Pakistan. The Navy was placed on high alert, prompting Pakistan to issue NAVAREA warnings amid fears of a possible naval strike. At the heart of the deployment was the Carrier Battle Group INS Vikrant, sources said, accompanied by 8 to 10 warships, forward deployed into the Arabian Sea. This marked one of the Indian Navy’s largest real-time operational movements outside routine peacetime exercises. The deployment included seven destroyers equipped with BrahMos missiles, Medium-Range Surface-to-Air Missiles (MRSAM), and Varunastra heavyweight torpedoes, capable of engaging surface, aerial, and underwater threats. Also in position were seven stealth guided-missile frigates, including the newly inducted INS Tushil, forming a formidable naval wall off the western coast. An estimated six submarines operated in close coordination below the surface, adding a stealth component to India's maritime posture. The operation also saw participation from fast attack crafts and missile boats, bringing the total number of assets to around 36—outnumbering the Pakistan Navy, which currently fields fewer than 30 warships. Pakistan’s naval fleet reportedly remained confined within Karachi harbour, unable to respond effectively due to the Indian Navy’s overwhelming presence. The heightened risk even led to international commercial vessels re-routing to avoid the tense waters around Karachi. The Indian armed forces launched Operation Sindoor on May 7 to avenge the Pahalgam attack where 26 people - mostly tourists – were killed. india_today.title: Gavai to be CJI for 6 months, first woman CJI might serve just 36 days
india_today.text: Justice Nagarathna will create history becoming the first female Chief Justice of India and the longest serving female judge in the Supreme Court. (Image Credit: File/Supreme Court of India) Justice Bhushan Ramkrishna Gavai, who was sworn in on Wednesday as the 52nd Chief Justice of India, will serve as the CJI till November 23. If Gavai's six-month tenure looks short, one needs to consider that the probable first woman CJI would have a term of just 36 days. It has been 75 years since the Supreme Court of India was established and yet, no woman has been appointed as the CJI. Justice Gavai's name was recommended by the collegium as the next CJI and the President granted her approval. Justice Gavai will be serving as the top judicial officer for six months, the same as the current CJI, Sanjiv Khanna. Until now, all 51 Chief Justices of India have been men and only 11 women have served as judges on the Supreme Court. As per the seniority rule, Justice BV Nagarathna will become the first woman Chief Justice of India in 2027. Even though her tenure will last for a mere 36 days, it will not be the shortest. The shortest serving CJI was Justice Kamal Narain Singh, whose tenure lasted just 17 days. This rule is linked to the duration that Supreme Court judges serve as the CJI and has been debated, as the tenures are associated with stability and effectiveness. While Justice Yeshwant Vishnu Chandrachud served as the Chief Justice of India for 7 years and 139 days, the longest ever, Justice Kamal Narain Singh served the shortest tenure of merely 17 days. Following him was Justice S Rajendra Babu, who served for 29 days and, if the seniority rule is followed as it is, Justice BV Nagarathna will be serving the third-shortest tenure served by a Chief Justice, which is 36 days. The 40th Chief Justice of India, Palanisamy Gounder Sathasivam, remarked on the short tenure of CJIs, saying, "There were many things that I wanted to do but couldn't do due to (my) short tenure," two days before demitting office. History was created when Justice Fathima Beevi became the first woman judge to be appointed to the Supreme Court in 1989, but she served the shortest tenure of 2 and a half years out of all the appointed woman judges to the apex court. Even as BV Nagarathna will retire after serving the longest term a female justice has served on the Supreme Court, of 6 years 2 months, her tenure as the 54th CJI will last just 36 days. Justice BV Nagarathna will become the first woman Chief Justice of India in its 75-year history. She will also hold the record of having served the longest tenure as a woman judge in the apex court, that is, six years and two months. Conclusively, as her father, Justice ES Venkataramiah, served as the 19th CJI, hers will be the second father-child duo in the history of India to have served as Chief Justices of India.

india_today.text: Star India batting duo Rohit Sharma and Virat Kohli will continue to retain their Grade A-plus contract despite their recent retirement from Test cricket. As the senior duo called their time on the longest format of the game, a section of fans wondered if they would continue to retain their Grade A-plus category contracts announced by the BCCI in April 2025. Since the contracts were handed for the time period between October 1, 2024 - September 30, 2025, the duo will remain in A-plus category. “Both players (Virat and Rohit) are playing for India, so why the question of not having them in A+ category? Both will continue in the same grade and will get all the facilities of that grade,” Saikia told India Today. Traditionally, the BCCI hands the A-plus contract to the top-performing players playing all three formats. In the current cycle, Ravindra Jadeja, Jasprit Bumrah, Virat Kohli and Rohit Sharma have been included in the A-plus contracts. india_today.title: Cabinet approves new HCL-Foxconn semiconductor plant near Jewar Airport
india_today.text: The HCL-Foxconn joint venture will establish the unit in Uttar Pradesh, strategically located near the upcoming Noida International Airport at Jewar. The Union Cabinet on Tuesday approved the establishment of a new semiconductor manufacturing unit near the upcoming Noida International Airport at Jewar, under the India Semiconductor Mission. The project will be executed by a joint venture between India’s HCL Group and Taiwanese electronics giant Foxconn. This marks another critical milestone in India’s push to build a vibrant domestic semiconductor ecosystem, reduce reliance on imports, and position itself as a key player in the global chip supply chain. With five semiconductor facilities already in advanced stages of construction, the new unit will be the sixth under the Mission, further strengthening the country’s high-tech manufacturing base. The HCL-Foxconn plant will be set up in the Yamuna Expressway Industrial Development Authority (YEIDA) region and is designed to produce display driver chips used in mobile phones, laptops, automobiles, personal computers and other electronic devices with visual displays. The facility is expected to handle a monthly capacity of 20,000 wafers, with an output of up to 36 million units per month. HCL brings decades of hardware development experience, while Foxconn is one of the world’s largest electronics manufacturers, giving the partnership both technical depth and global scale. The upcoming HCL-Foxconn plant adds momentum to a strategic shift that’s been years in the making, but success will ultimately depend on how quickly these projects scale and integrate with global supply chains.

india_today.text: The Supreme Court on Friday rejected all the petitions seeking the complete verification of votes cast using Electronic Voting Machines (EVM) with Voter Verifiable Paper Audit Trail (VVPAT) slips. india_today.title: Russian woman calls India her 'peaceful home', applauds Indian Army in video message
india_today.text: A Russian national residing in Gurugram shared a video on Instagram in which she expressed her deep gratitude towards the Indian Army amid heightened tensions between India and Pakistan. Not only did Polina Agrawal call India her "peaceful home", but she also applauded the dedication of its soldiers who have been relentlessly safeguarding the nation, especially since Operation Sindoor, under which India carried out precision strikes on terror camps in Pakistan and Pakistan-occupied Kashmir (PoK) on May 7. The military action came in response to the killing of 26 civilians by terrorists in Jammu and Kashmir’s Pahalgam on April 22. Draped in a yellow saree, Polina shared the video message after receiving a call from her grandmother in Russia, who urged her to return home following recent news reports. Polina’s response, however, was resolute: "What home? I am home right now, here in Gurugram." Praising India's defence capabilities, Polina also said, “The Indian military has got such advanced weapons and air defence systems which Russia itself has provided. It stays so strong against all the drones or jets or planes or anything that tries to fly in.” “Indian soldiers have such immense dedication and such big hearts so we can sleep peacefully at night. They risk their lives so we live whatever lives we were living before. And we do not even notice there is anything going on. I am so deeply grateful to them for their dedication and I can call India my peaceful home,” she added. Another user added, “Russia has always been a great friend to us. Thank you for the military aid - rest assured, as a Russian, you have saved many lives.”

india_today.title: Tesla Optimus robot shows impressive dance moves in new video
india_today.text: Tesla’s humanoid robot Optimus is back in the limelight, and this time, it’s not for factory tasks or tech upgrades — it’s for dancing. A short video shared by Elon Musk on the social media platform X shows the robot performing fluid and expressive dance moves, prompting many viewers to wonder if what they saw was even real. The video quickly gained traction, with millions of views and widespread engagement. While some social media users questioned whether the clip was generated using artificial intelligence, Musk clarified that the footage was genuine and happening in real time. X’s own chatbot, Grok, also responded to one user’s query, stating the clip likely showed the actual Optimus robot. The AI cited previous demonstrations, including Tesla’s ‘We, Robot’ event in October 2024 and updates from April 2025, as proof that the robot had already shown off basic tasks like walking and coordination. Social media users were both amused and amazed. One user joked about turning Optimus into a wall painter, saying Tesla would sell millions if that were the case. Another praised the robot’s capabilities, suggesting that such innovations could reduce work-related physical injuries once deployed at scale. Tesla originally revealed its plans for a humanoid robot during its AI Day in 2021, though at that time it was more of a concept — quite literally, with a person dressed in a robot costume dancing on stage. In 2022, Tesla brought early prototypes to life, showcasing limited but functioning mobility. Since then, the robot has gradually developed into a more advanced machine capable of carrying out simple real-world tasks. The new video suggests that Tesla is not only making technical progress but also building public interest in Optimus through relatable moments. Whether the robot will be painting walls, working in warehouses or helping at home, the latest glimpse adds to the growing curiosity about its future role in society.

india_today.title: Realme GT 7 and GT 7T India launch set for May 27: What to expect
india_today.text: Realme is all set to expand its Realme GT 7 series in India, with two new phones expected to join the GT 7 Pro — the Realme GT 7 and GT 7T. For those who don’t know, Realme has already released the GT 7 duo in China, but until the Indian versions are officially unveiled, we can’t be certain how similar they’ll be to their Chinese counterparts. Interestingly, the Chinese variant of the GT 7 closely resembles what is being referred to as the GT 7T in India. In fact, there isn’t a GT 7T model in China at all. On top of that, the Indian version of the GT 7 isn’t getting the Dimensity 9400+ chip found in the Chinese variant. It’s a bit of a confusing situation, which is why we’re focusing solely on the Indian versions of the upcoming Realme GT 7 phones. Here’s everything we know so far. Realme has officially confirmed that both the GT 7 and GT 7T will launch globally — including in India — on May 27. The launch event is set to take place in Paris, France, with the start time scheduled for 1:30 PM IST. Both phones are expected to go on sale via Realme’s official website, Amazon India, and across other online and offline retail channels. While Realme hasn’t revealed any pricing just yet, we can take some clues from last year’s GT 6 series. The Realme GT 6 and GT 6T launched in India at starting prices of Rs 40,999 and Rs 30,999, respectively. So, it’s fair to expect the GT 7 and GT 7T to be priced similarly. Realme GT 7 series: Specs and expected features Unlike its Chinese counterpart, which runs on the Dimensity 9400+ chip, the Indian version of the Realme GT 7 is confirmed to be powered by the MediaTek Dimensity 9400e processor. It’s also expected to pack a massive 7,000mAh battery with support for 120W fast charging. The Chinese version features a slightly larger 7,200mAh battery, but what’s coming to India still looks very promising. Another highlight is that the Realme GT 7 is being marketed as the world’s first smartphone to feature a graphene cooling layer beneath both the rear panel and the display. This should, at least in theory, deliver improved thermal management and help the phone stay cool even under intense use. The phone is also confirmed to be available in two colour options: IceSense Blue and IceSense Black. Other key features expected on the Realme GT 7 include a 6.78-inch full-HD+ OLED display with a 144Hz refresh rate, a dual rear camera setup with a 50-megapixel primary sensor, and a 16-megapixel front-facing camera for selfies and video calls. As for the Realme GT 7T, there’s still limited information available about the device. So far, it’s said to launch with 8GB RAM. The device carries the model number RMX5085 and has reportedly been spotted on the TKDN certification site in Indonesia. Realme has also confirmed that the GT 7T will come with NFC support. Additionally, it will feature something called INT, which is believed to function similarly to Apple’s Intercom feature — allowing users to send and receive short voice messages between devices, such as from one GT 7T to another, or across compatible Realme devices. According to the phone’s official landing page, the Realme GT 7T will come in three colours: blue, black and a signature yellow with a black strip design.

india_today.title: Zomato changes Gold Membership benefits, now in rain it won't help you much
india_today.text: Zomato is set to make a change that could disappoint many of its loyal Gold members. Starting May 16, the company will begin charging an additional rain fee even for users subscribed to its Gold membership plan — a cost that was earlier waived as part of the perks. Here is everything we know about it. The latest change was quietly announced via the app, and we have received the notification about it, just as the monsoon season begins to make its way into several Indian cities. Rain surcharges — typically ranging between Rs 15 and Rs 35 — have long been applied during bad weather, but Gold users were previously shielded from it. That will no longer be the case. So far, Zomato Gold has offered benefits like free delivery from nearby partner restaurants and rain fee waivers. But now, while free delivery under 7km and up to 30 per cent dining discounts remain, the added cost during rain could make frequent ordering more expensive. It’s worth noting that Zomato Gold still includes unlimited free deliveries from select outlets, excluding a few such as Domino’s and others that manage their own logistics. These partner restaurants carry a “Free Delivery” tag to help users identify them. It is worth noting that the company already charges a fee during the festive season, something which Zomato acknowledged, saying: "This fee helps us pay our bills to keep Zomato running. To maintain services during the festive season, it has increased slightly," That said, the removal of the rain fee exemption could reduce the overall value of the Gold membership for many users — especially during monsoon months when such charges become frequent. Whether customers continue to see the membership as worth the price remains to be seen.

india_today.title: Tesla AI software boss Ashok Elluswamy reveals how it is working with Elon Musk, says he is very funny
india_today.text: Tesla's top position holder, Ashok Elluswamy, recently opened up in an interview about his experience working closely with Elon Musk. In a podcast with YouTuber Gobinath, the Vice President of AI Software at Tesla revealed a few internal details, including how it is to work with the founder, Elon Musk. Additionally, he also spoke about the future of AI and predicted what it will be like in the next 10 years. The senior executive, who has his roots in Tamil Nadu, reflected on his journey from southern India to leading one of the most high-profile tech teams in Silicon Valley — and on the unique experience of working with one of the world’s most influential tech entrepreneurs. Speaking about Musk’s work ethic and personality, Elluswamy said, “I meet with him every week. He is really smart in the sense that he can predict the future very early. He works really hard. Easily 80–90 hours per week. I feel fortunate to work for him. He is not afraid of taking risks. He is very funny. You can see it in person.” Elluswamy’s remarks highlight the demanding pace and innovation-driven culture at Tesla. His weekly interactions with Musk, he said, offer him a window into the billionaire’s relentless pursuit of progress and his willingness to make bold decisions — characteristics often cited as key to Musk’s success. The conversation gained traction on social media after Tesla investor Sawyer Merritt shared a snippet on X (formerly Twitter), drawing widespread interest from fans of the brand and Musk’s leadership style. Merritt quoted Elluswamy’s comments verbatim, further amplifying praise for Musk’s foresight, risk appetite, and humorous side. As Tesla continues to push boundaries in autonomous driving and artificial intelligence, Elluswamy remains a key figure behind the scenes. In the podcast interview, he noted that all the cars manufactured in 2035 will be self-driving. He added, "If you want, as a hobby to drive a car, you can buy an old car." But he hinted that driver-less cars are the future. He announced that Tesla is expecting to launch driver-less cars in some cities in the US. Explaining the driver-less cars, Elluswamy said that it is a continuous progression of technology. It is a combination of the software and the drive, with a lot of driver monitoring technology, he said. Right now, he explained, cars are highly dependent on drivers. But in the future, technology will take care of all of it. "We don't need supervision, we will handle everything safely and if anything happens, the car is responsible," he added. When asked about EVs and AI-powered cars in India, Elluswamy said, "I am not an expert in the Indian market." He said, while in the US the cities are far away and a layperson needs a lot of range to cover the cities, India has much less distance to cover. As batteries make up a significant portion of a car’s cost, he hinted that EVs in India tend to be far more affordable than their counterparts in the United States.
