cnbc_tv18.title: Tredence: Where AI expertise, domain mastery, and fearless innovation converge
cnbc_tv18.text: Tredence’s story begins in 2013, when a team of six set out to solve a stubborn analytics gap: the last-mile AI problem. Organisations were spending heavily on data projects, yet insights rarely reached day-to-day decision-makers. Tredence pledged to close that gap, and in barely a decade has grown into a 3,500-strong global force in AI and data science. Much of that momentum flows from Tredence’s reputation as a career springboard for elite talent. Learning is not a perk here; it is the operating system. New hires enter personalised pathways that mix technical mastery with deep industry immersion. Whether they work in retail, CPG, or healthcare, engineers and data scientists move beyond code to master merchandising levers, dynamic pricing, patient-centric workflows and supply-chain dynamics. Instead of handing over glossy dashboards that gather dust, Tredence teams invest in adoption strategies, user training and operational readiness. That last-mile rigour is why clients see real ROI rather than shelf-ware. The company also refuses to separate domain consulting from data science. On a typical consumer-goods assignment, supply-chain specialists and data scientists share the same war room—and the same performance metrics. The cross-functional model pays off: one retailer’s media network saw ad revenue quadruple in a year, while a regional grocery chain unlocked more than $200 million through sharper demand forecasting. Tredence’s fearless approach to innovation amplifies this domain focus. Spotting the potential of generative and agentic AI early, the firm created Milky Way Agents—autonomous helpers that learn continuously, orchestrate workflows and relieve humans of repetitive grind. These AI-driven assistants sift vast data sets, flag anomalies and surface instant insights, freeing people to concentrate on strategy and creativity. Augmentation, not substitution, is the goal. A culture of relentless upskilling keeps that engine humming. Company-wide hackathons throw recruits and veterans alike into real-time industry challenges; internal academies, global collaborations and peer mentorship ensure skills stay current as AI evolves. Curiosity is institutionalised, risk-taking celebrated and rapid iteration the norm. Strategic partnerships extend that edge. Tredence collaborates with hyperscalers such as Google, AWS and Microsoft, and with data platforms like Databricks and Snowflake. Sitting on product advisory boards gives the firm early line-of-sight into road-maps and lets it co-develop domain accelerators. Clients gain faster access to cutting-edge capabilities—be it a tailored generative-AI engine for retail content or a specialised ML pipeline for healthcare analytics. Commercial wins aside, Tredence is leaning into social and industry-wide impact. Supply-chain optimisation work reduces waste—a gain for both the environment and the bottom line—while AI-driven patient-engagement models help providers coordinate care more effectively. The message: data-driven decisions can create more sustainable and equitable outcomes when wielded responsibly. The road ahead is audacious. Tredence aims to become the most indispensable AI and data-science partner for half of the Fortune 500. I In April 2025 it welcomed Further Advisory—a banking and financial-services consulting firm—into the fold to help global BFSI clients modernise faster, manage risk smarter and unlock scalable growth. Rather than bracing for disruption, Tredence frames agentic AI as the next logical step in professional services and plans to guide enterprises through that landscape, marrying data-modernisation efforts with domain-led solutions built for complex realities. From a three-bedroom apartment to a trusted ally of global giants, Tredence proves that genuine innovation fuses fearless experimentation with an obsession for outcomes. As industries race to embed AI, the company stands ready with domain fluency, agentic-AI firepower, strategic partnerships and a growing commitment to social value. Just as Disney expanded from a single animation studio into a storytelling empire by blending content, experience and technology, Tredence is stitching together an enterprise-AI ecosystem designed for impact at scale—showing that the journey from insight to action can be swift, meaningful and transformative when fuelled by fearless execution.

cnbc_tv18.title: ‘National security over business’: Shiv Sena demands Turkish firm’s ouster from Mumbai airport
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeIndia News‘National security over business’: Shiv Sena demands Turkish firm’s ouster from Mumbai airport The Shiv Sena has demanded the immediate termination of a Turkish ground-handling company’s contract at Mumbai’s international airport, citing national security concerns over Turkey’s alleged support for Pakistan in recent drone-related activities. On Monday, Shiv Sena leader Murji Patel led a delegation to Mumbai International Airport Limited (MIAL), calling for an end to its association with Celebi NAS Airport Services, which currently handles around 70% of ground operations at Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport. “Turkey may not be firing weapons directly, but supplying drones that are used to target our borders is no less than a hostile act,” said Patel. “We cannot allow a country that supports our enemy to make money off Indian infrastructure.” The Sena has given MIAL a 10-day deadline to cancel the contract, warning of protests if no action is taken. According to Patel, the party has already met with the airport’s CEO, who has promised to review the matter and respond within the timeframe. The protest has found support beyond political circles. Traders from Pune have backed the Sena’s demand and announced a halt on importing Turkish products, signalling a wider move towards economic disengagement from countries seen as aiding Pakistan. Sena leaders insisted the demand was not politically motivated but based on national interest. “This is not a business issue—it’s a matter of principle,” said a party worker. “We are talking about a country that helps arm our enemies. Why should we let them profit here?” Also read: Operation Keller: 3 terrorists killed in encounter with security forces in J&K's Shopian With tensions high on India’s borders and drone threats increasing—particularly in regions such as Punjab and Jammu—concerns about Turkey’s defence ties with Pakistan have fuelled a surge in economic nationalism. The Shiv Sena’s demand reflects this sentiment, drawing attention to foreign firms operating in sectors linked to critical infrastructure. Whether or not MIAL acts within the 10-day window, the Sena’s message is clear: companies from nations that support hostile actions against India should not be allowed to operate in key infrastructure projects. The party’s warning reinforces a broader view that in a time of heightened external threats, national security must take precedence over commercial interests. Also read: Operation Sindoor | Pakistan Army says 11 soldiers killed and 78 injured in conflict with India

cnbc_tv18.title: Muzaffarnagar riots case: Court acquits 11 citing lack of evidence
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeIndia NewsMuzaffarnagar riots case: Court acquits 11 citing lack of evidence A fast-track court in Muzaffarnagar has acquitted eleven people accused in the 2013 Muzaffarnagar riots case, citing lack of evidence, a government lawyer said on Tuesday, May 13. According to government counsel Narendra Sharma, the Special Investigation Team (SIT) had filed a chargesheet against the eleven accused — Subhash, Papan, Manvir, Vinod, Pramod, Narender, Ram Kishan, Ramkumar, Mohit, Vijay, and Rajender — under Indian Penal Code sections 395 (dacoity) and 436 (mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to destroy house, etc.). The case was registered based on a complaint filed by Umerdeen, a resident of Lisadh village under Phugana police station. He alleged that a mob had broken into his home on September 8, 2013, during the communal violence in Muzaffarnagar. The attackers allegedly looted cash and jewellery worth lakhs of rupees and later set his house on fire, Sharma said. Following the incident, Umerdeen and his family fled the village and took shelter in Jhinjhana town of Shamli district, he said. The Muzaffarnagar riots of 2013 had left over 60 people dead and thousands displaced, leading to multiple cases being investigated by the SIT. cnbc_tv18.title: Economists see inflation staying soft through FY26; rate cut window widens
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeEconomy NewsEconomists see inflation staying soft through FY26; rate cut window widens India’s retail inflation fell to 3.16% in April — the lowest year-on-year (YoY) print since July 2019 — with economists across the board now expecting inflation to remain soft through FY26, opening space for rate cuts. The April print marked the sixth consecutive monthly decline in headline inflation, helped by a steep drop in vegetable and pulse prices. Food inflation cooled sharply to 1.78% from 2.69% in March, while rural and urban inflation dipped to 2.92% and 3.36%, respectively. Sakshi Gupta, Vice President and Senior Economist at HDFC Bank, noted that April’s figure was close to their forecast of 3.11%, adding, “Continued decline in cereals and pulses is encouraging and bodes well for future CPI prints. We expect inflation to stay between 3-3.2% for the next two months.” She projected FY26 CPI at 3.7%, with a terminal repo rate of 5.5% and two rate cuts — one each in June and August. ICRA Chief Economist Aditi Nayar flagged a likely dip in June inflation and expected FY26 CPI at 3.5%, well below RBI’s 4% target. “That opens up space for rate cuts,” she said, pencilling in a 75 bps cut in this cycle, starting with a 25 bps reduction in the upcoming policy. Anubhuti Sahay of Standard Chartered Bank also said Q1FY26 inflation might undershoot RBI’s forecast, citing a benign food inflation trajectory and falling global commodity prices. “We expect average FY26 CPI at 4%, with a downside risk. If growth decelerates, we might see further cuts,” she said, maintaining a terminal repo rate view of 5.5%. ALSO READ | US inflation slows in April despite tariffs, down 0.1% from March Devang Shah, Head of Fixed Income at Axis Mutual Fund, too expects softer inflation over the next two months. “Looking at the CPI trajectory, a 35 bps rate cut is given,” he said, noting that global cues would also influence domestic bond markets. Economists, however, cautioned that seasonal spikes in vegetable prices remain a risk. But for now, the sharp and broad-based cooling in prices has opened the door for the RBI to consider policy easing — especially as inflation appears likely to stay below its 4% target in the near term.

cnbc_tv18.title: US inflation slows in April despite tariffs, down 0.1% from March
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeWorld NewsUS inflation slows in April despite tariffs, down 0.1% from March Inflation in the United States slowed for the third consecutive month in April, despite new rounds of import tariffs introduced by President Donald Trump. However, many economists believe this respite may be temporary, with price pressures likely to intensify over the coming months. Figures released by the US Labour Department on Tuesday show consumer prices rose 2.3% in April compared with the same period last year, down from 2.4% in March — the smallest annual increase in more than four years. On a monthly basis, prices edged up 0.2% after falling 0.1% in March, which had marked the first monthly decline in five years. President Trump’s tariffs — including a 10% universal duty imposed in early April and steep levies on steel, aluminium and Chinese imports — have yet to show their full effect on consumer prices. A significant reduction in US tariffs on Chinese goods, from 145% to 30%, was announced on Monday as part of a trade agreement between the two countries. Nonetheless, economists estimate the average US tariff now stands at 18%, about six times higher than before Trump took office. Items already in transit when the tariffs were announced are exempt from duties, and many businesses have stocked up in advance, allowing them to delay passing on the costs to consumers. That lag, however, is unlikely to last. Tariffs on goods such as furniture, clothing, and agricultural products from Mexico may already be pushing up some prices. Car prices may also have risen as buyers rushed to dealerships to avoid potential hikes, giving dealers less reason to offer discounts. Core inflation — which excludes food and energy — rose 2.8% year-on-year in April, matching March’s figure. On a monthly basis, core prices increased 0.3%, up from 0.1% the month before. cnbc_tv18.title: How Jalna’s young changemakers are protecting children from migration’s fallout
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeIndia NewsHow Jalna’s young changemakers are protecting children from migration’s fallout In the drought-prone district of Jalna, where poverty and migration disrupt childhoods, a quiet revolution is taking place. A group of young people, known as Balmitras (friends of children), are stepping up to protect the most vulnerable. These youth volunteers, aged 18 to 29, ensure that children left behind when their parents migrate for work are not left alone, unsupported, or unsafe. Jalna, in central Marathwada, is one of the worst-affected regions in the state in terms of agrarian distress. Droughts, poor irrigation, and repeated crop failures have led to chronic poverty, pushing families—especially those from Scheduled Castes and Tribes—into seasonal migration. Parents move to sugarcane farms, brick kilns or construction sites in search of work, often taking their children along. These children face unsafe living conditions, disrupted schooling, and a lack of healthcare and nutrition. Some are forced into child labour or early marriage. Those who remain behind with relatives or older siblings also face emotional neglect and limited access to basic services. The Balmitras’ main role is to raise awareness about the risks of unsafe migration and promote kinship care, where children stay in villages under the care of grandparents, relatives, or trusted neighbours. Through individual and group counselling with parents, they help families choose this safer alternative. The Balmitras also run after-school programmes three times a week, offering academic support, games, life skills, and psychosocial care for children of migrant workers. These sessions provide a safe and nurturing space for children to grow, learn, and express themselves. Balmitra Bhimrao Tambe, a 30-year-old youth from Jalna district, has worked in this initiative for two years. His dedication has earned him the title of Master Balmitra—a mentor role in which he trains and appoints new Balmitras across villages. “When a girl refuses child marriage and chooses to continue her education, it feels like I’ve done something truly meaningful,” he said with a smile. He and his fellow youth volunteers are being felicitated by the Jalna Collector for their contribution to child education and protection. Currently, Jalna district has 649 Balmitras working across six blocks. Since 2014, the percentage of children staying back in family-based care during migration seasons has steadily grown, reaching 60.23% in 258 pilot villages. In 2024–25 alone, over 5,800 children stayed back in kinship care. Most were cared for by grandparents, others by extended family or trusted community members. A small number lived independently with siblings in child-headed households. This community-based care model is showing outcomes such as low school dropout rates, continued access to nutrition and health services, and a reduction in child labour, early marriage, and teen pregnancies. The model has now been scaled up to 198 more villages, led by the Jalna District Collector and the State Migration Committee of the Department of Women and Child Development. Balmitras receive no monetary compensation but gain skills, confidence, and purpose. “The training they receive—on child rights, communication, community mobilisation—helps shape their personalities and future careers. Some of our former Balmitras have even gone on to become Sarpanch, leading their villages,” said Ravi Kelgaonkar of SACRED. Bhausaheb Gunjal from Gramin Vikas Pratishthan agreed. "Balmitras play a big role in preventing child marriage. They engage with young girls and their parents, convincing them to delay marriage and support education. We’ve seen many girls who once resisted early marriage now excelling academically and winning awards in school,” he added. For thousands of children in migration-affected communities, the Balmitra initiative provides a support system. It ensures continuity in education, safeguards mental health and helps children grow up in a more secure environment. It is becoming a blueprint for other districts across Maharashtra. Alpa Vora, Child Protection Specialist at UNICEF Maharashtra, said, “In Jalna, thousands of children are forced to migrate with their families due to drought and poverty. They miss school, live in unsafe conditions, and lose access to basic services. The Balmitra initiative is changing this. Trained youth volunteers now help children stay in their villages, attend school, access health services, and participate in after-school and mental wellbeing activities. This model is not just protecting children—it is transforming futures.” On 15 May, Jalna Collector Dr Shrikrishna Panchal will felicitate 400 Balmitras in Jalna City for their work and contribution.

cnbc_tv18.title: MSMEs face ₹30-lakh crore credit gap, women-owned units hit hardest: SIDBI report
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeBusiness NewsFinance NewsMSMEs face ₹30-lakh crore credit gap, women-owned units hit hardest: SIDBI report A new report by the Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI) has revealed that India’s micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs) face an estimated credit gap of ₹30 lakh crore. The gap, which equals about 24% of the sector’s total credit requirement, rose sharply to 35% for women-owned MSMEs. The report, titled 'Understanding Indian MSME Sector: Progress and Challenges,' is based on a survey of over 2,000 MSMEs across 19 sectors. It presents a detailed picture of the sector’s growth, digital shift, and ongoing structural challenges. Despite formal policy support, MSMEs, especially micro units, continue to struggle with timely and adequate access to credit. The report found that 12% of micro enterprises still rely on informal borrowing, compared to just 2-3% in small and medium units. Women-led MSMEs now make up 26.2% of proprietary enterprises, according to ASUSE 2023-24. While 76% of these businesses have access to credit, 41% report that limited access and intense competition hinder their growth. Around 18% of MSMEs now use digital lending platforms, and 90% accept digital payments — highlighting a steady shift toward tech-driven finance. However, market access remains a bottleneck. About 70% of MSMEs still rely on traditional marketing, limiting scalability and competitiveness. The share of MSMEs in India’s merchandise exports rose from 43.6% in FY23 to 45.7% in FY24. Export-oriented MSMEs demonstrate higher tech adoption but still face barriers like supply chain issues and credit limitations. Sustainability is also gaining ground: 31% of surveyed MSMEs use energy-efficient systems, while 21% rely on renewable energy. However, 33% cite limited awareness as the biggest barrier to further adoption. The sector has witnessed rapid formalisation through platforms like Udyam Registration and Udyam Assist. Registered MSMEs jumped from 2.5 crore in March 2024 to over 6.2 crore by March 2025. A quarter of respondents said they face skilled labour shortages — particularly in sectors like defence manufacturing, garments, hospitality, and tiles. Meanwhile, infrastructure and technology gaps continue to impact firms in auto components, iron and steel, and logistics. SIDBI’s report pointed to the urgent need for targeted interventions — especially for women entrepreneurs, digitally lagging firms, and service sector MSMEs. Enhancing credit flows, improving digital outreach, and boosting sustainability awareness could help the sector unlock its full potential.

cnbc_tv18.title: No practice matches, no problem: Inside Virat Kohli’s intense training regime
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeSports NewsNo practice matches, no problem: Inside Virat Kohli’s intense training regime Former Indian bowling coach Bharat Arun has said that Virat Kohli disliked practice matches and instead preferred training on spicy pitches by asking pacers to have a go at him from 16 yards ahead of important encounters. "He never liked practice matches," Arun recalled. "He always felt the intensity was somehow missing and never really enjoyed practice games. Instead, he would want to spend more time at the nets and would always choose the spiciest wicket and get bowlers to bowl at him from 16 yards — or take throw downs from 16 yards. The fact is — he always needed a challenge. That's what got him going," he added. Arun went down the memory lane to remember an important moment before the Boxing Day Test match of the Border-Gavaskar Trophy in 2018-19 when the series was tied 1-1. "Virat had just scored a fantastic hundred at Perth but we did not win that match," he said. "Going into Melbourne, it was Virat who literally changed the dressing room mindset. He made everyone believe that we could do it and went about his business as leader in a manner unrivalled." India clinched an important win in that game, securing a 2-1 series win, which was a first for the country on Australian soil. Kohli brought curtains down to his career with the help of 9230 runs in 123 Tests, comprising 30 centuries, and an average of 46.85. His 40 wins as the Test captain is the most by any Indian skipper. "He respected the format more than anything else and will be missed," he concluded.

"You attacked them head-on. You destroyed major terrorist hideouts. He emphasised that the operation had not only destroyed terror infrastructure but also the "nefarious designs" and "audacity" of Pakistan, as per ANI. "Operation Sindoor is India's new normal," Modi asserted. "You have shown the Pakistan Army that there is no location in Pakistan where terrorists can sit at peace. We will go inside and finish them and won't give them a chance to retaliate," he added. Read more: Air Marshal AK Bharti: 'We did not hit Kirana Hills'

cnbc_tv18.title: Acer Aspire C27 Review: A budget-friendly all-in-one PC
cnbc_tv18.text: The Acer Aspire C27 makes a compelling case as a value-driven alternative to premium all-in-one (AIO) desktops, offering solid performance and a space-saving design for users on tighter budgets. Starting at around ₹60,990, it lands between two extremes: The pricey Apple iMac 27-inch, with its class-leading Retina display, and more limited options like HP’s compact Chromebase. At a glance, the Aspire C27 could pass for a standard monitor. Its slim profile, minimalist bezels, and V-shaped stand help it blend unobtrusively into a workspace. But under the surface, it’s a complete Windows 11-based desktop PC — the review unit was powered by 12th-Gen Intel Core i5-12450H, 16GB of DDR4 RAM, and a 1TB SSD. There are other configurations depending on users' needs. From a hardware standpoint, the Aspire C27 covers many essentials. The internals are well suited for everyday productivity — think spreadsheets, web browsing, video calls, and even a bit of photo editing. The system runs quietly thanks to efficient mobile-grade components and rarely draws attention to itself with fan noise. It’s well-optimised for typical home or office tasks, delivering smooth performance for general Windows workloads. In terms of build, the Aspire C27 is compact. The design hides all the components behind the lower half of the screen, while downward-firing speakers bounce audio off the desk surface. The sound is surprisingly loud and clear, though it lacks the low-end presence that a front-facing speaker bar or subwoofer might provide. The 27-inch full HD (1920x1080) display is perhaps the Aspire C27’s weakest link. On paper, it offers a generous screen size with a 90.71% screen-to-body ratio, but the resolution doesn’t quite match the panel’s real estate. Text and icons look soft, and individual pixels are noticeable from a normal viewing distance — a problem more common on smaller, lower-resolution screens. The brightness, measured at just 216 nits, is adequate for indoor use but well below the 300-nit baseline many users would expect. The Aspire C27 features a 5MP 'Super HD' webcam in some models — a welcome improvement over the standard 720p unit found in other configurations. It’s supported by Acer PurifiedView, which helps improve clarity during video calls. This marks a step up from the grainy, underexposed images seen on many entry-level AIOs. Acer bundles a wireless keyboard and mouse, which is a welcome touch at this price point. The keyboard is functional and comfortable, while the compact mouse gets the job done — though many users may want to upgrade to a full-size option for daily use. The Aspire C27 isn’t built for gaming or heavy media production, but it handles day-to-day computing with ease. Benchmarks place it solidly in the mid-range for Windows AIOs, trailing premium options like the iMac but keeping pace with other budget and mid-tier rivals. It can even manage light video or photo editing, though its integrated graphics (or modest MX330 GPU, if equipped) rule out anything beyond casual gaming. The Acer Aspire C27 is a practical, no-nonsense all-in-one that delivers where it matters most: Solid performance, sleek design, and a price tag that makes it an attractive iMac alternative. It’s well suited to students, professionals working from home, or anyone looking for a clean, clutter-free setup without breaking the bank. Its biggest flaws — namely the low-resolution display and lack of USB-C — don’t ruin the experience, but they do put it a step behind more premium rivals. If Acer offered a higher-resolution panel option, the C27 could easily stand out as a top pick in the mid-range AIO segment.

cnbc_tv18.title: India-Pakistan tensions: Mahira Khan, Fawad Khan, Mawra Hocane removed from Bollywood song posters

cnbc_tv18.title: CMF Phone 2 Pro Review: A budget beauty that gets the basics right
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeTechnology NewsCMF Phone 2 Pro Review: A budget beauty that gets the basics right CMF, the budget-focused sub-brand from Nothing, made its debut last year with the CMF Phone 1 — a device that won over value-conscious buyers. It wasn’t without its faults, though: No charger in the box, no protective case, and a middling camera setup left a few boxes unticked. Now, CMF returns with the Phone 2 Pro — a device that promises a more polished experience, better specs, and even modular accessories to boot. Priced at ₹18,999, it sits in one of the most competitive segments of the smartphone market. The CMF Phone 2 Pro keeps the modular spirit of its predecessor alive, but this time, it’s more refined. It’s the thinnest phone CMF has produced to date, measuring just 7.8mm and weighing 185g — comfortably slim and light in the hand. The back panel is no longer removable, but the phone retains its signature screw-in wheel for attaching accessories, now redesigned to sit flush with the frame. A 120Hz adaptive refresh rate ensures smooth scrolling, and the 1,000Hz touch sampling rate makes the phone feel especially snappy during games or fast-paced navigation. CMF has opted for Panda Glass over Gorilla Glass, which is slightly less-known but should still offer decent protection. Powering the CMF Phone 2 Pro is MediaTek’s Dimensity 7300 Pro chipset, paired with 8GB of RAM and either 128GB or 256GB of storage. There’s also the option to add 8GB of virtual RAM for a smoother multitasking experience. It’s not the fastest chip in its class, but in everyday use, the Phone 2 Pro is more than capable. Apps open quickly, switching between tasks is smooth, and light gaming is handled well. CMF has promised three years of major Android updates and six years of security patches, which is generous for a phone at this price. The minimalist aesthetic of Nothing OS complements the hardware nicely, with smooth animations and a focus on usability over flash. The CMF Phone 2 Pro isn’t trying to be the flashiest or the fastest phone under ₹20,000 — and that’s precisely what makes it so appealing. It focuses on getting the fundamentals right: Good design, decent performance, a great display, and a surprisingly versatile camera setup. Throw in a clean software experience and modular accessories that actually add value, and you’ve got a device that feels more considered than many of its peers. If you’re after a stylish, reliable handset that dares to do things a bit differently, the CMF Phone 2 Pro is easy to recommend.

cnbc_tv18.title: Here's why Greg Chappell calls Virat Kohli the most Australian non-Australian cricketer ever
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeSports NewsHere's why Greg Chappell calls Virat Kohli the most Australian non-Australian cricketer ever Australian legend Greg Chappell understands that Virat Kohli's Test retirement is the end of a thunderous era where he eclipsed Sachin Tendulkar and carved a cultural and psychological impact in Indian cricket. Chappell wrote in his ESPNCricinfo article that Kohli's long career was a reign defined by grit, fire, and audacity. "It closes the chapter on the most transformative figure in Indian cricket since Sachin Tendulkar; perhaps Kohli even eclipses him in terms of cultural influence and psychological impact on India's cricketing identity," Chappell wrote. "Kohli, the incandescent heart of Indian cricket for over a decade, did not just score runs. He redefined expectations, challenged conventions, and symbolised the self-assured, unapologetic India of the 21st century," he added. Kohli hung his boots from the red-ball format and explained that he was walking away from the format with a heart full of gratitude. "Virat Kohli is the most Australian non-Australian cricketer we've ever seen," Chappell wrote. "He was - a snarling warrior in whites, never giving an inch, always demanding more. Not just of his bowlers, his fielders or his opposition, but first and foremost, of himself," he said. Chappell further added that Kohli exiting Test matches was a seismic shift in energy. "There was a time when Indian cricket, particularly overseas, bore an air of respectful submission - playing with technical skill, yes, but often with psychological inferiority. "That changed in stages. Sourav Ganguly gave Indian cricket a new spine. MS Dhoni brought ice-cold leadership and white-ball dominance. But Kohli? Kohli lit the fire. He tore the script and authored a new one, where India was not just competitive abroad but expected to win," he explained. The former Indian head coach applauded the batter for transforming India's approach in Test cricket, and described Kohli as an exceptionally perceptive individual. "Where others reacted, Kohli anticipated. He saw innings before they unfolded. He lived the pressure before it arrived. "Yes, Tendulkar was a genius. Yes, Dhoni was a master tactician and an ice-cold finisher. But in the grand reckoning of Indian cricket history, Kohli has been its most influential figure," he said. "Why? Because he changed not just results but mindsets."

cnbc_tv18.title: India’s tablet market sees strong start to 2025, led by Apple, Samsung and Xiaomi: CMR
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeTechnology NewsIndia’s tablet market sees strong start to 2025, led by Apple, Samsung and Xiaomi: CMR India’s tablet market posted a robust 15% year-on-year (YoY) growth in the first quarter of 2025, fuelled by rising demand from consumers and enterprises for premium and 5G-enabled devices, according to the latest data from CyberMedia Research (CMR). The growth was most pronounced in the premium segment, which expanded 41% compared to the same period last year. 5G-enabled tablets now account for 43% of total shipments, a clear sign that Indian consumers are increasingly opting for future-ready devices. Samsung maintained its lead with a 34% market share, followed by Apple at 21% and Lenovo at 19%. Xiaomi followed closely with a 16% share, riding high on the performance of its Xiaomi Pad 7, which contributed 36% of premium tablet sales in the quarter. Source: CyberMedia Research “Indian consumers are increasingly aspirational, driving demand for the latest and most advanced devices to support work, learning, and entertainment,” said Prabhu Ram, VP, Industry Research Group, CMR. Ram said the iPad’s success is propelled by Apple’s strong brand equity and the seamless integration of its ecosystem, which he said remains a key differentiator valued by users seeking a unified experience across devices. "On the Android front, Samsung stands out as the only brand consistently delivering a competitive premium experience, with features such as vibrant displays, robust security, productivity modes, and long-term software support. Beyond Samsung, most Android tablet users prioritise value-for-money offerings, with brands like Xiaomi gaining significant traction.” Apple recorded 18% YoY growth, driven by strong shipments of the iPad 11 Series, which made up 49% of its total volumes. The recent launch of the iPad Air (2025) is expected to further support Apple’s position in the months ahead. Also read: India not ready to take on China's share of iPhone manufacturing: Report Samsung’s growth was largely powered by the Galaxy Tab A9 Plus 5G, which alone contributed 98% of its shipments. Lenovo’s Tab M11 and M9 helped the brand maintain third position, although growth remained muted. Xiaomi, meanwhile, saw a substantial YoY growth of 59%, boosted by its continued appeal in the value-premium segment. “Brands like Samsung, Apple, Lenovo and Xiaomi capitalised on evolving consumer expectations with differentiated offerings across price tiers,” said Menka Kumari, senior analyst at CMR, adding, “The tablet market is gaining momentum in the premium segment, driven by aspirational consumers seeking high performance and ecosystem value.” Looking ahead, CMR expects the Indian tablet market to grow at a steady 10–15% through the rest of the calendar year. The research firm sees increasing demand around the academic admissions season, as well as during upcoming festive promotions. AI-powered features, improved cameras and deeper ecosystem integration are also likely to influence purchase decisions. With over 100 countries now importing Indian tablets and the market becoming more diverse in its offerings, India’s tablet space is evolving rapidly — combining both global brand presence and rising local demand for performance-driven devices. cnbc_tv18.title: SpiceJet resumes flights from Srinagar; Hajj 2025 operations to start on May 14
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeBusiness NewsAviation NewsSpiceJet resumes flights from Srinagar; Hajj 2025 operations to start on May 14 Days after India and Pakistan reached an understanding to cease firing and shelling at the borders, low-cost airline SpiceJet resumed flight operations to and from Srinagar. According to an official statement from the budget carrier, the decision was effective from Tuesday, May 13. The airline said the Hajj 2025 flights from Srinagar would start from May 14. The first scheduled flight, SG 9835, will take off from Delhi for Srinagar at 2:30 pm today, with the return flight scheduled for 4:30 pm. The IATA-IOSA certified airline will commence its operations for this year’s pilgrimage from Srinagar tomorrow, with two flights to Medina using wide-body Airbus A340 aircraft that can accommodate 324 passengers each. It will facilitate the travel of around 15,500 pilgrims in 2025, the airline said in a statement. On Monday, the airline said it would resume operations from airports that were temporarily closed in the wake of Pakistani drone attacks in border districts. #TravelUpdate: We are pleased to inform you that airports previously affected are now open for operations, as per the latest government directives. Our teams are actively working to resume normal flight operations at the earliest. We appreciate your patience and understanding… — SpiceJet (@flyspicejet) May 12, 2025 "We are pleased to inform you that airports previously affected are now open for operations, as per the latest government directives. Our teams are actively working to resume normal flight operations at the earliest. We appreciate your patience and understanding during this time," it wrote. Earlier, on May 2, the airline commenced its Hajj 2025 operations with an inaugural flight from Gaya to Medina. It also mentioned that it planned to operate 45 Hajj flights from Gaya, Srinagar, Guwahati, and Kolkata to Medina and Jeddah in the first phase. This year's Hajj is likely to take place between June 4 and June 9, 2025, depending on moon sighting. The annual pilgrimage to Mecca and Medina is performed during a particular period that culminates with Eid-ul-Adha. Saudi Arabia's Interior Ministry recently announced strict rules for individuals planning to perform the pilgrimage. The ministry announced substantial fines, deportations and entry bans for anyone performing or facilitating the pilgrimage without proper permits. The penalties are effective from April 29 (1 Dhul-Qi'dah) to June 10 (14 Dhul-Hijjah) to enable smooth crowd control during the Hajj season. As per the reports, Saudi Arabia has also temporarily suspended certain visa categories from several countries to prevent unregistered pilgrims and manage crowds effectively.

cnbc_tv18.title: GSK Pharma Q4 Results: Net profit at ₹260 crore; ₹42 dividend declared
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeMarket NewsGSK Pharma Q4 Results: Net profit at ₹260 crore; ₹42 dividend declared For the quarter ended March 31, 2025, GlaxoSmithKline Pharmaceuticals Ltd. reported a revenue of ₹966 crore, a like-to-like growth of 6%. Profit for the quarter stood at ₹260 crore. The company reported full year revenue of ₹3,723 crore, a growth of 9%. Profit increased by 32% to ₹915 crore and EBITDA margins increased by 500 basis points to 31.4%. “We remain committed to delivering sustained above-market growth and strong shareholder returns. In FY2025-26, we will continue to focus on our innovative portfolio through the launch of our oncology assets,” he added. The company said its on track to launch Zejula (Niraparib), a PARP inhibitor for ovarian cancer and Jemperli (Dostarlimab), an immunotherapy approved for the second-line treatment of endometrial cancer. The board has recommended a final dividend of ₹42 per equity share on face value of ₹10 each for the year ended March 31, 2025, subject to approval of members at 100th Annual General Meeting. Record date for the said dividend has been fixed as May 30, 2025. Shares of GlaxoSmithKline Pharmaceuticals Ltd. ended 3.22% higher at ₹2,809. The stock has risen over 25% so far in 2025.

cnbc_tv18.title: Union Bank launches 'Union Wellness Deposit' scheme with health insurance and lifestyle benefits
cnbc_tv18.text: HomePersonal Finance NewsUnion Bank launches 'Union Wellness Deposit' scheme with health insurance and lifestyle benefits Union Bank of India has launched a new retail term deposit scheme called the 'Union Wellness Deposit'. The scheme combines fixed deposit benefits with health insurance and lifestyle perks. The deposit has a fixed tenure of 375 days. It offers an interest rate of 6.75% per annum, with an additional 0.50% for senior citizens. Customers can invest a minimum of ₹10 lakh and up to ₹3 crore. Premature closure and loans against the deposit are allowed. A key feature of the scheme is a 375-day Super Top-up Health Insurance cover worth ₹5 lakh, which includes cashless hospitalization. The product also offers lifestyle benefits via the RuPay Select Debit Card. The scheme is open to resident individuals aged 18 to 75, either individually or jointly. In joint accounts, only the primary holder gets the insurance cover. A fixed deposit (FD) is a type of savings product where customers deposit a lump sum amount for a fixed tenure at a predetermined interest rate. It is a low-risk investment that provides guaranteed returns and is a popular option for individuals looking to save securely. ALSO READ | These banks have reduced home loan interest rates in May

cnbc_tv18.title: Trump Residences in Gurgaon sold out on day 1 with ₹3,250 crore in allotments, claim developers
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeReal Estate NewsTrump Residences in Gurgaon sold out on day 1 with ₹3,250 crore in allotments, claim developers All 298 homes, including ultra-premium penthouses, of Trump Residences Gurgaon were booked on the day of launch, Smartworld Developers and Tribeca Developers announced on Tuesday. Calling it one of India’s most historic luxury real estate launches, the two companies, working in collaboration with the Trump Organization, said they registered an unprecedented ₹3,250 crore in allotments. The amount included bookings for penthouses worth a total of ₹125 crore, they added. Priced between ₹8 crore and ₹15 crore per residence, Trump Residences Gurgaon comprises two 51-storey towers and offers what developers described as the most ‘prestigious addresses in the country.’ While Smartworld will oversee development, construction, and customer service of the project, Tribeca will lead design, marketing, sales, and quality control, the two companies said in a statement. Kalpesh Mehta, the founder of Tribeca Developers, said that Trump Residences Gurugram was not just a real estate project but a landmark moment for the country's luxury market. “Selling ₹3,250 crore on Day 1 places this among the biggest luxury deals the country has ever seen,” he said. The launch proves the unmatched magnetic pull of the Trump brand and how deeply it resonates with India’s most discerning buyers, he added. “We are proud to have raised the bar once again, delivering iconic, globally benchmarked luxury alongside Smartworld and The Trump Organization.” This is the second Trump-branded residential development in North India. In 2018, Trump Towers Delhi NCR, launched in Gurugram, is fully sold out and is set for delivery later this month, the statement read.

cnbc_tv18.title: Qatar's Boeing 747-8 jet gift to serve as Trump's Air Force One: All about the giant aircraft
cnbc_tv18.text: HomePhotos NewsWorld NewsQatar's Boeing 747-8 jet gift to serve as Trump's Air Force One: All about the giant aircraft The President will use the 13-year-old plane until shortly before the end of his second term in office. US President Donald Trump is preparing to accept a Boeing 747-8 aeroplane as a gift from the Qatari royal family. Dubbed 'palace in the sky', the luxury plane costs approximately $400 million and will replace Air Force One. The President will use the 13-year-old plane until shortly before the end of his second term in office, when it will be transferred to his presidential library. (Image X) According to a report in Axios, the US and Qatar were negotiating the price of the giant aircraft, when Qatar came back and said, “We'll just gift it. It's OK.” “And it's gifted to the people of the United States, gifted to the Department of Defense. And it's supposed to be ready by the end of the year,” a top administration source added. (Image: Reuters) Speaking with reporters on Monday, Trump said, “I think it's a great gesture from Qatar.” “I appreciate it very much. I would never be one to turn down that kind of an offer. I mean, I could be a stupid person saying: 'No, we don't want a free, very expensive aeroplane," he added as reported by Sky News. (Image X) As per reports, it is the same jet the US leader toured at Palm Beach International Airport earlier this year. Earlier on Sunday, Trump said in a post on his Truth Social platform that the aircraft is free to temporarily replace Air Force One. (Image Reuters) “So, the fact that the Defense Department is getting a GIFT, FREE OF CHARGE, of a 747 aircraft to replace the 40-year- old Air Force One, temporarily, in a very public and transparent transaction, so bothers the Crooked Democrats that they insist we pay, TOP DOLLAR, for the plane,” he wrote. (Image YouTube) The aircraft features a master bedroom, a guest bedroom, two full bathrooms with showers, nine smaller restrooms, five small kitchens and a private office. (Image X) The soon-to-be Air Force has the capacity to hold about 90 passengers and 14 crew members, as per the Daily Mail. (Image X) The plane has been equipped with giant couches and recliners, wood panelling, and over 40 televisions, including ten large-screen TVs. The private Boeing 747 was originally used by a division of Qatar Airways that serves the country's royal families and other government dignitaries. (Image X) It has been modified to fit five distinct lounges throughout the aircraft's two major decks, connected by a luxurious staircase. The massive plane has only five rows of standard business class seating. The plane also includes all of the latest air travel amenities, such as live TV and radio access, 13 Blu-ray players and internet connectivity. (Image Wikipedia) As per the Business Jet Traveller, it is considered one of the most lavish in the world. The inside of the plane, designed by renowned French interior design firm Alberto Pinto Cabinet, features elaborate suites, staterooms, lounges and dining areas. (Image Wikimedia Commons) The plane's corridors are decorated with reflective, gold-coloured walls reminiscent of Trump's design choices at his own properties, including Trump Tower in Midtown Manhattan. The conference room includes beautiful tan and cream chairs with deep cushions that can be adjusted with the touch of a button. (Image Reuters) The 747-8 will be given a significant upgrade to ensure it is ready for the commander-in-chief once it is handed over to the US Department of Defense, the Daily Mail reported, (Image X)

cnbc_tv18.title: ONDC appoints Vibhor Jain as acting CEO amid leadership transition
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeBusiness NewsRetail NewsONDC appoints Vibhor Jain as acting CEO amid leadership transition The Open Network for Digital Commerce (ONDC) has named Chief Operating Officer Vibhor Jain its acting CEO with immediate effect, as the organisation moves to a single-point leadership structure during its search for a permanent Managing Director and CEO. Jain, who is also a member of ONDC’s eight-member Executive Committee, will now assume full executive responsibilities. The transition brings an end to the interim leadership role played by the committee over the past few weeks, ONDC said in a press release. “The Executive Committee has done a commendable job of guiding ONDC during a critical phase of its journey. However, with several key strategic decisions underway, it is imperative to have a single point of leadership to drive cohesive execution,” said Suresh Sethi, ONDC Board Member. “Vibhor has played a pivotal role in shaping ONDC’s operational framework, and the Board has full confidence in his ability to lead the organisation during this important transition.” Jaxay Shah, also a member of the Board, added, “As Vibhor steps into the role of Acting CEO, the Board is confident in his ability to lead with clarity and purpose. His deep experience and unwavering commitment to ONDC’s mission make him well-suited to guide the organisation forward as we continue to build an inclusive and open digital commerce ecosystem. We also acknowledge the Executive Committee for helping ensure continuity during the recent transition period.” In his first comments as Acting CEO, Jain said, “It is an honour to take on this responsibility at a time when ONDC is expanding its footprint and impact across the country. I am committed to working closely with the Board, stakeholders, and the broader ecosystem to ensure continuity and momentum as we deliver on our mission to democratise digital commerce in India.” ONDC has crossed several milestones since its launch, including more than 200 million transactions in under three years. The network is part of India’s broader push to create foundational digital public infrastructure and is seen as a key initiative in transforming the digital commerce landscape through greater accessibility and inclusivity.

cnbc_tv18.title: US to boost Saudi access to AI chips even as China issues linger
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeWorld NewsUS to boost Saudi access to AI chips even as China issues linger The Trump administration is preparing to announce a deal granting Saudi Arabia more access to advanced semiconductors, paving the way for increased data center capacity in the Gulf nation despite concerns from some US officials about its ties to China, according to people familiar with the matter. The agreement would boost Saudi Arabia’s ability to buy chips from the likes of Nvidia Corp. and Advanced Micro Devices Inc., which are considered the gold standard for training and running artificial intelligence models, said the people, who asked not to be identified discussing confidential conversations. President Donald Trump is in Riyadh Tuesday, kicking off a broader Middle East trip, and he could announce the deal as soon as this week. But while the two governments have reached an early-stage accord, they are still hashing out a number of key details, the people said. Front and center are US concerns that China could access chips sent to Saudi Arabia, either through the diversion of physical shipments or by tapping the capabilities of those chips via the cloud. One provision under discussion, the people said, would see the US government control access to data centers that use American chips. It’s not clear under what conditions, or to whom, access would be granted. Also read: US to cut 'de minimis' tariff on China shipments to 54% from 120% Representatives for the Saudi Arabian government and the White House didn’t immediately respond to requests for comment. The deal is one of two major AI chip accords that Trump officials are negotiating as they prepare to rewrite US rules governing the export of advanced chips worldwide. Trump may announce the second agreement with the United Arab Emirates later in his trip, Bloomberg has reported. Taken together, the deals indicate that Trump is much more willing than President Joe Biden to see advanced American technology shipped to the Gulf — a region where he also has major business interests and where sovereign wealth funds have pledged substantial investments in the US.

cnbc_tv18.title: Borosil Renewables sees India growth picking up, Europe still under pressure
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeMarket NewsEarnings NewsBorosil Renewables sees India growth picking up, Europe still under pressure Volume growth and better realisations have led to a turnaround in the earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) of Mumbai-based solar glass manufacturer Borosil Renewables. Pradeep Kheruka, Executive Chairman at Borosil Renewables said, “We have been selling in the past at a very low price, trying to match the dumped prices coming from China, which was selling well below the actual cost of production, even for them. The other thing is also a growth in volume. We have achieved a growth in volume as well as a growth in prices.” Borosil Renewables posted a turnaround in January-March quarter 2025 (Q4FY25) results, with EBITDA rising to ₹15.5 crore, a reversal from losses seen in the same period last year. It reported a revenue of ₹373 crore and loss of ₹20 crore. As of now, domestic prices are stabilising at around ₹54,000 per tonne. While the domestic market has improved, Borosil's European subsidiary remains under pressure, posting monthly losses of €800,000 to €900,000. The segment was hit hard by a flood of low-cost Chinese solar modules in 2024, which led to a shutdown of several EU-based manufacturers. “But hopefully from July, we should see a downturn in that. If we start production of tempered glass there based on imported glass, then that should reduce the loss by more than half. The moment we have a little more firm news about resumption of production, then that will cause, hopefully, the loss to go away and maybe even some profits to be seen,” Kheruka added. Borosil Renewables has secured board approval to increase its production capacity by 500 tonnes per day. While there is potential to scale up beyond this level based on available equipment, the company is currently limiting its guidance to the approved 500 tonnes, in line with what has been formally communicated to the stock exchanges. Borosil Renewables’s current market capitalisation is ₹6,885 crore. The stock is currently trading at ₹526 as of 3:30 pm on the NSE and has gained 6% over the last year. Follow our live blog for more updates on Q4 results

cnbc_tv18.title: India's retail inflation drops to 3.16% in April, lowest in over five years
cnbc_tv18.text: India’s retail inflation based on the Consumer Price Index (CPI) eased to 3.16% in April 2025, marking the lowest year-on-year rate since July 2019, according to provisional government data released on Monday. The decline of 18 basis points from March’s 3.34% reading offers fresh comfort for policymakers amid a sustained disinflationary trend. The fall was led by a sharp drop in food inflation, which stood at 1.78% in April compared to 2.69% in March—a 91 basis point decline. This is the lowest food inflation rate since October 2021. A significant moderation was observed in the prices of vegetables, pulses, fruits, cereals, meat and fish, and personal care items. Rural inflation slowed more sharply, falling to 2.92% in April from 3.25% in March. Rural food inflation dropped to 1.85% from 2.82%. In urban areas, inflation dipped to 3.36% from 3.43%, while urban food inflation saw a more pronounced decline to 1.64% from 2.48% in March. Among key components, housing inflation was stable at 3.00% (vs 3.03% in March), while education inflation ticked up to 4.13% from 3.98%. Health inflation remained flat at 4.25%. Notably, fuel and light inflation jumped to 2.92%, from 1.42% the previous month. Transport and communication inflation rose to 3.73% from 3.36%.

cnbc_tv18.title: Premature redemption due today for these gold bonds: What happens if you miss the window
cnbc_tv18.text: HomePersonal Finance NewsPremature redemption due today for these gold bonds: What happens if you miss the window The premature redemption due date for Sovereign Gold Bond (SGB) 2017-18 Series VII and 2018-19 Series III is Tuesday, May 13, 2025. If you miss submitting a redemption request, here’s what you need to know. Redemption price and returns The redemption price for both SGB tranches is ₹9,551 per unit, based on the average closing price of 999 purity gold on May 8, 9, and 12, 2025, as published by the India Bullion and Jewellers Association (IBJA). These gains are tax-free, but the 2.5% annual interest on the face value is taxable. What happens if you miss redemption today? If you fail to submit a redemption request today, you cannot redeem prematurely until the next eligible redemption date. This opportunity typically arises every six months, on the next interest payout date. You will continue holding the bonds until the next redemption window opens. Experts advise checking with your bank or depository participant well in advance of such dates. For demat account holders, a redemption request can be submitted through the depository participant. It must be noted that the government in Union Budget 2025 discontinued fresh issuances of the Sovereign Gold Bond scheme. However, existing bonds remain active and will be redeemed on schedule or on eligible early redemption dates.

cnbc_tv18.title: Stocks retreat as Nifty, Sensex slide; Midcaps buck weak trend
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeMarket NewsStocks retreat as Nifty, Sensex slide; Midcaps buck weak trend Indian equity indices ended lower on Tuesday, surrendering part of Monday's rally, as weakness in IT and financial stocks weighed on the benchmarks. The Nifty 50 fell 346 points to close at 24,578, while the Sensex dropped 1,282 points to end at 81,148. The Nifty Bank index slipped 442 points to 54,941. IT stocks reversed Monday's gains, dragging the Nifty IT index 2% lower, while SRF pared intraday losses and closed 3% down after upbeat commentary on its chemicals business. Among midcaps, UPL tumbled 5%, becoming the top laggard after it provided a weaker-than-expected FY26 outlook. Swiggy fell 3% as its shareholder lock-in period ended, while Eternal, Chambal Fertilisers, Oracle Financial Services Software, REC, and Torrent Power were among the other major midcap losers. Hindalco shed 3% after its U.S. unit Novelis refrained from offering FY26 guidance, dampening investor sentiment. Tata Motors slipped 1% ahead of its quarterly earnings release.

cnbc_tv18.title: SoftBank Vision Funds post annual 40% loss despite the group's return to profit
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeBusiness NewsSoftBank Vision Funds post annual 40% loss despite the group's return to profit SoftBank’s Vision Fund investment arm posted a loss for the financial year ended March, as gains slowed sharply across its tech portfolio. The drop in performance came even as the broader group recorded its first annual profit in four years. The Vision Funds registered investment gains of ¥434.9 billion over the year, down 40% from the ¥724.3 billion reported in the previous year. The segment recorded a pre-tax loss of ¥115.02 billion (approximately $778 million), compared with a profit of ¥128.2 billion the year before. In the fiscal fourth quarter, covering the three months to March, the Vision Funds posted a modest gain of ¥26.1 billion, helped by a rise in the valuation of SoftBank also recorded gains from its investments in Didi and South Korean e-commerce firm Coupang. However, declines in the value of other portfolio companies such as AutoStore weighed on the fund’s overall performance. Also read: Apple working to move to AI search in browser amid Google fallout The Vision Funds remain a key area of interest for investors watching for signs of recovery in SoftBank’s investment strategy, particularly after the segment delivered a surprise loss in the third quarter. SoftBank’s investment business continues to be shaped by broader swings in financial markets. The company’s stock is down around 17% this year, amid persistent market volatility and concern over the global economic outlook. Despite the drag from the Vision Funds, SoftBank Group reported a full-year profit of ¥1.15 trillion, its first since 2021. The performance was driven by gains in long-standing holdings, including Alibaba, T-Mobile and Deutsche Telekom. Contributions from chip designer Arm and the group’s domestic telecommunications business also supported the result.

cnbc_tv18.title: Cricket Australia backs player's choice to return from IPL despite WTC final clash
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeSports NewsCricket Australia backs player's choice to return from IPL despite WTC final clash Cricket Australia on Tuesday said it will support its players' "individual decisions" on returning to the Indian Premier League (IPL), even as the resumption of the T20 tournament is set to clash with preparations for the World Test Championship (WTC) final. The BCCI decided on Monday to resume the IPL season across six venues from May 17, with the final slated for June 3. The development leaves Australia's and South Africa’s Test regulars in a dilemma, as the WTC final between the two nations is slated to begin on June 11 at Lord’s. "Following the announcement that the IPL will resume on Saturday, Cricket Australia will support players in their individual decisions whether to return to India or not,” CA said in a statement. "Team management will work through the preparation implications for the World Test Championship final for those players who choose to play in the remaining IPL matches. "We are maintaining communication with the Australian government and BCCI around security arrangements and safety." The IPL was suspended last Friday due to a military conflict between India and Pakistan. According to the revised schedule, the tournament would end just eight days before the WTC final in London where Australia face South Africa. In the wake of the unrest, several Australian players, including skipper Pat Cummins and fast bowler Mitchell Starc and Josh Hazlewood have returned home. Only a few former players like Ricky Ponting and Brad Haddin, who are part of coaching setups, remain in India. Other coaches, including Justin Langer and Mike Hussey, have returned home amid the rising border tensions. Australian Test players currently involved in the IPL who are likely to be impacted include captain Cummins and Travis Head (both Sunrisers Hyderabad), Starc (Delhi Capitals), and Hazlewood (Royal Challengers Bengaluru). While SRH are out of the playoff race, second-placed RCB are well-positioned to qualify, and fifth-placed DC remain in contention.

cnbc_tv18.title: UK's M&S says customer data was taken in cyber attack
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeBusiness NewsUK's M&S says customer data was taken in cyber attack British retailer Marks and Spencer, opens new tab said on Tuesday some personal customer information was taken in the cyber attack that has crippled its online operation for more than three weeks. M&S, one of the best known names in British business, stopped taking online orders on April 25, and its share price has fallen 15% since the Easter weekend, when problems with orders first started. The retailer, whose 1,000 stores remain open, is widely reported to have been the victim of a ransomware attack, where criminals infiltrate companies' computer systems, encrypt them and demand payment before allowing them to resume control. M&S said some customer details had been taken, blaming the "sophisticated nature" of the incident, and said it would inform customers of the issue. "Importantly, the data does not include useable payment or card details, which we do not hold on our systems, and it does not include any account passwords," M&S said in its statement. "There is no evidence that this data has been shared." Advising customers there was no need to take any action, the company said work was continuing to get operations back to normal. It said it had taken steps to protect is systems, while working with cybersecurity experts, law enforcement and government agencies. M&S has declined to quantify the financial impact, which is growing by the day as it misses out on sales of new season ranges with much of the UK basking in warm May temperatures. It makes around one-third of its clothing and home sales online. Analysts at Deutsche Bank estimated earlier this month that the profit hit would have been at least 30 million pounds and the run rate at about 15 million pounds a week. They said cyber insurance would likely cover most of the impact but that cover is generally provided for a limited amount of time.

cnbc_tv18.title: GAIL Q4 Results: Net profit nearly halves, revenue misses estimates
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeMarket NewsGAIL Q4 Results: Net profit nearly halves, revenue misses estimates State-run GAIL reported results on Tuesday, May 13, which were a miss on estimates across topline and bottomline parameters, but the operational metrics were in-line with expectations. Revenue for the quarter increased by 2.1% from last year to ₹35,685 crore from ₹34,937 crore last year. The figure was below the CNBC-TV18 poll of ₹37,042 crore. Net profit for the period nearly halved to ₹2,049 crore and was marginally below expectations of ₹2,153 crore. GAIL's Earnings Before Interest, Tax, Depreciation and Amortisation (EBITDA) for the quarter increased by 13.3% year-on-year to ₹3,215 crore, which was in-line with expectations of ₹3,260 crore, while margins expanded by 90 basis points from the previous quarter to 9% from 8.1% in December. The EBITDA margin figure was also in-line with the CNBC-TV18 poll of 8.8%. Brokerage firm JM Financial in its first cut after the results said that GAIL's standalone EBITDA was lower than their estimates due to a weaker-than-expected EBIT in the petchem segment and marginally lower EBIT in the gas transmission and trading segment. GAIL has earmarked a capex plan of ₹10,000 crore for financial year 2026, which will be utilised for the petchem, equity investments, pipelines and the LNG vertical. The management also said that there has been an impact on profitability due to the cut in supply, but operations are continuing through a mix of both new and old well gas. Shares of GAIL are down to the lows of the day, currently trading 2% lower at ₹184. The stock is up 2.7% in the last one month.

cnbc_tv18.title: These banks have reduced home loan interest rates in May
cnbc_tv18.text: HomePhotos NewsPersonal Finance NewsThese banks have reduced home loan interest rates in May In May 2025, several Indian banks adjusted their Marginal Cost of Funds-Based Lending Rates (MCLR), impacting loan interest rates and Equated Monthly Installments (EMIs) for borrowers. These changes reflect the banks' responses to evolving economic conditions and the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) monetary policy decisions. Bank of Baroda reduced its one-year MCLR by 5 basis points, bringing it down from 9.00% to 8.95%, effective May 12, 2025. Other tenures, including overnight, one-month, three-month, and six-month MCLRs, remain unchanged. The overnight rate stands at 8.15%, while the six-month rate remains at 8.80%. The one-year MCLR is the most commonly used benchmark for home and auto loans, and the reduction is likely to offer slight EMI relief to borrowers. Canara Bank reduced its MCLR selectively, with a 5 basis point cut in the overnight tenor, now at 8.30%. The two-year MCLR was also lowered by 10 basis points to 9.25%. However, other tenures were left unchanged. Punjab National Bank announced a broader reduction in lending rates across all tenures, also effective from May. The overnight MCLR dropped by 15 basis points to 8.25%, while the one-month and three-month rates were cut by 10 basis points each. The bank’s one-year MCLR, a key reference for most consumer loans, was brought down from 9.05% to 8.95%. PNB also lowered its three-year MCLR from 9.35% to 9.25%. HDFC Bank announced a reduction in its Marginal Cost of Funds-based Lending Rates (MCLR) by up to 15 basis points across select loan tenures. Following the revision, effective from May 7, 2025, HDFC Bank's MCLR now ranges between 9.00% and 9.20%, depending on the loan tenure. This is a decrease from the previous range of 9.10% to 9.35% that was applicable in April 2025.

cnbc_tv18.title: Chalet Hotels confident of double-digit revenue growth in FY26
cnbc_tv18.text: Chalet Hotels is confident of delivering double-digit revenue growth in 2025–26 (FY26), supported by strong demand across both its hospitality and annuity businesses. “We’ve still grown at 12% over the May of last year,” said Sethi, referring to a few cancellations in leisure bookings due to geopolitical uncertainty. The company expects growth from both existing hotels and new assets that are being added to its portfolio. It aims to cross 5,000 operational and pipeline rooms over the next four to five quarters. Chalet Hotels reported a good set of fourth-quarter numbers, slightly better than the industry. Revenue and margins were strong, and average room rates increased by 21%. These are the edited excerpts of the interview. Q: Good end to Q4 and to the financial year. What are you targeting for this year when it comes to revenue? And could you break that down for us in terms of increased occupancy, rates, and also annuity revenue, which is margin accretive? A: We've had a very strong Q4. It’s been record-breaking on all parameters and it’s in line with what we've been saying, that the industry continues to have tailwinds for the foreseeable future. On the macro front, the next three to four years will be very strong, where demand will outpace supply. So, we’ll see some small occupancy improvements in stabilised hotels, but more importantly, we should see rate improvements going forward. The current situation over the last couple of weeks had us concerned. We took contingency steps to freeze costs and closely monitor the situation. Looking ahead, I’m hopeful June business will be back in full swing. In May, we've lost some business but we’ve still grown 12% over May of last year. So growth is still on track. We believe we will see double-digit growth from existing hotels, and as we add new ones, inorganic growth will also kick in. The office assets are moving into provisioning and leasing very quickly. We had an exit rate of ₹21 crore in March, and this month we’ll probably hit ₹25 crore, which means ₹300 crore in annual rentals, with about 95% flow-through. Hospitality continues to be our largest segment across both leisure and business hotels. Q: What about the cancellations you saw in May and the impact. What was the percentage of cancellations and any specific impact on your northern properties? A: The leisure hotels saw cancellations for MICE (Meetings, Incentives, Conferences, and Exhibitions) movement due to uncertainty last week. We hope many of those will return, as they’ve pushed dates rather than cancelled outright. Subject to availability, they could help us recoup some lost business. As of May 12, we’re still 12% over the same period last year. We’re currently about 6-9% shy of our internal targets, but this isn’t a massive hit by any means. Q: From a growth standpoint, you’ve earlier said FY26 will see several assets come on stream and FY27 is where growth really shows. You have around 3,300 keys now and 1,250 under development. That’s around 30% capacity push. Your annuity assets should also grow by 10-20%. If FY25 revenue ended near ₹1,700 crore and FY26 gets you to ₹2,000 crore, are we looking at ₹2,500 crore in FY27 with 40%+ margins? A: We don’t give forward-looking numbers, but I’d say your numbers aren’t far off. We have our internal assessment and believe we’ll do better than that. So yes, ₹2,500 crore is achievable by FY27. On margins, we’ve delivered 46-47%, so not just 40% but well above that. As office assets mature, margins will also improve. Q: On the balance sheet, you deleveraged a bit via QIP and later acquired Western Himalayas, which added about ₹500 crore in debt. Where does net debt stand now, and what's the deleveraging plan? A: Net debt is just under ₹2,000 crore. We’ve taken enabling resolutions to raise ₹1,000 crore in future if needed just to keep dry powder ready for growth opportunities. Most of the announced pipeline will be funded by internal cash flows. But we want to be ready to act on new opportunities. Our goal is to cross 5,000 rooms across operational and pipeline hotels over the next 4-5 quarters. Q: You have two new properties, Western Hyderabad and the Khandala retreat. When will they reflect fully in your P&L? A: The Westin Hyderabad, part of the Western Himalayas acquisition, has been operational since around February 10-12. So, it was reflected for about 40+ days in FY25. It’s still ramping up. Current occupancies are around 43-45%, with ARRs at ₹27,000–₹28,000. We expect it to stabilise at about 60% occupancy. At our Dukes Retreat in Khandala, 73 rooms are operational. A banquet facility will be ready by the end of this month. Once we expand to 145 rooms, we expect this property to contribute meaningfully starting October this year.

cnbc_tv18.title: Flamboyant opener Sam Konstas finds a place in Australia's 15-man squad for WTC final against South Africa
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeSports NewsFlamboyant opener Sam Konstas finds a place in Australia's 15-man squad for WTC final against South Africa Flamboyant opener Sam Konstas and fit-again all-rounder Cameron Green found a place in Australia's 15-man squad for next month's World Test Championship final against South Africa in London, where Pat Cummins and his men would be aiming to retain the coveted mace. "Those series capped a consistent performance across the two-year cycle and now presents us with the incredibly exciting opportunity to defend the World Test Championship (from June 11 to 15 at the Lord's) . "It means a lot to the group to reach the final and they are very much looking forward to the challenge South Africa will present at Lord's," he added. Konstas was sent home from the tour of Sri Lanka after failing to make the squad and was playing for New South Wales. He made an exciting debut against India in the fourth Test in Melbourne but could not continue the momentum subsequently. Green was laid low by a back injury that needed surgery last year. Spinner Matt Kuhnemann has been included as the backup for regular Nathan Lyon, while Brendan Doggett has been named as a travelling reserve. The same squad will then head to the West Indies for a three-Test series in Barbados, Grenada and Jamaica from June 25. Cummins and Josh Hazlewood, both of who sat out of the Test series against Sri Lanka and the subsequent Champions Trophy due to injuries, are back in the squad after successfully returning to action during the Indian Premier League. Mitchell Starc, and Scott Boland make up the rest of the pace attack. South Australia's Doggett will be the back-up pacer in case of an injury breakdown. The right-arm pacer began well in his ongoing county stint with Durham, claiming nine wickets in his first two matches. Australia squad for WTC final: Pat Cummins (c), Scott Boland, Alex Carey, Cameron Green, Josh Hazlewood, Travis Head, Josh Inglis, Usman Khawaja, Sam Konstas, Matt Kuhnemann, Marnus Labuschagne, Nathan Lyon, Steve Smith, Mitchell Starc, Beau Webster. Travelling reserve: Brendan Doggett.

cnbc_tv18.title: Lupin's new drug launch could contribute over 25% of its FY26 earnings, analyst says
cnbc_tv18.text: HomeMarket NewsLupin's new drug launch could contribute over 25% of its FY26 earnings, analyst says Shares of Lupin Ltd shares gained nearly 4% on Tuesday, May 13, as the pharma company launched the Tolvaptan tablets or Jynarque generic in the US market. Axis Capital said Lupin is expected to be the only generic player for the most of the financial year 2026. The company's revenue opportunity for the ongoing fiscal is estimated at $150 million to $200 million. The gTolvaptan drug can contribute over 25% to Lupin's FY26 earnings and can be a major driver for its performance in this fiscal, Axis Capital said. The launch helps offset revenue loss from gMirabegron in FY26, the analyst added. Factoring all this, Axis Cap said it has revised its FY26 earnings before interest taxes depreciation amortisation (EBOITDA) and profit after tax (PAT) by 8% and 10%, respectively. Lupin is the first to file for this product and is eligible for 180 days of generic drug exclusivity. The drug is indicated to slow kidney function decline in adults at risk of rapidly progressing autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. It has a market size of $1.46 billion. The product will be manufactured at Lupin's Nagpur facility in India. Last month, Lupin received approval from the US Food and Drug Administration (USFDA) for its new drug application Tolvaptan in the 15 mg, 30 mg, 45 mg, 60 mg and 90 mg strengths. Lupin shares gained 3.56% to hit an intraday high of ₹2,114.3 apiece on Tuesday, May 13. The stock has declined 12.77% this year, so far.
